Robotee

How about electrical spikes causing the lights to go out in the room? Like a 10-25% chance. If that happens, doing things are harder to do (success chance decreased) and there's a higher chance of hurting yourself (and maybe other people too?)
On july 20, 2014
Necrodem

First of all I answer for Miner101X there is Defacer.

You need wait then nothing happends in room logs and in close period before cycle changes you can use this skill and free spiking.

And revive my ideas about new skills:

Mymic
Mush lv 13

Cost 2
Target: Human
Private level: Secret but will not logged if you allone with victum. Detected by Mycoalarms.

Change your model and room logs names for target. You safe your own treats and will not copy status/titles/treats from target(Terence`s copy model should be rework because he can walk). Last 1 turn. Ones per day maximum.

Something to good combo with Pirate Radio.


Blood bath
Mush lv9
Passive

For every human taken damage in room you recover 1.

Electroficator
Mush lv 16(swap Piromaniak)
Cost 3
Private level: Invisible

Call a Electrical Spike in room(all players include caller take 3 damage all equipment broken)

Empathy
Mush lv 4
Passive

Allow you to see all statuses of target(including illness) and give morale marger wich show how many morale target left. It is green when morale level 75%+, yellow when 25%+ and red if lower then 25%.

Repeating my earlier suggestion that we be able to see crewmate physical injuries in the same way we see dirtiness. You'd think it'd be obvious that somebody's tongue was torn out or their legs were smashed.

Also suggesting that Raluca have a cooldown on Schrodinger, rather than the same once-a-ship as everyone. It's her cat after all. Obviously once a day would be too strong, but I don't think once every three or five days would be unreasonable.

On july 21, 2014
[7971963]

I wouldn't mind if mush recovered a spore if they interacted with a trapped shelf. It could even be a tactic for Mush Paola and Finola.

Let's look at an interesting scenerio. A ship where the bridge does not have a camera.

Day 1-
Mush A (Let's say Raluca, Because Raluca is always mush) eats D2 and traps the refectory and CC. Along the way she does that normal thing of claiming to eat and getting dirty from it.

Mush B, Who is Paola, interacts with the shelves. By doing this she gains two spores for us! At the end of D1 she infects Frieda.

Day 2 -

Mush B infects Frieda again, and works on Xyloph. Deliberately trying to break the connection. She succeeds in C4.

Mush A then goes to the bridge to "Establish The connection". She infects Frieda, takes anonymush, and nobody is any the wiser. Of course, now frieda starts having some truely terrible luck with planets! Oh my! Volcanos everywhere!

-
It would make difficult mush like Paola and Frieda much more viable, or be a way that a Gioele/Stephen mush could give PA to an ally who needs it for their own cover. (Phagocyte: Look! I just gained AP from that Ration. I can't be mush. Listen, trust me, Ian is the mush. He's gotten dirty how many times?)
On july 21, 2014
Irishpolak

I like this idea! Like you said it gives mush at the front of the ship much more power to actually do something useful, and it's actually something that a crew can use to help discover Paola/Frieda mush easier, so it's got a good balance. Seeing a mush suspect frequent FC after suspected showers, and Paola making a few too many trips that way? You can keep an eye on Paola now. It gives both sides a good little boost to what they can do, without making one side too powerful against the other.

Offtopic, just few words about playing mush-Paola

If you are Paola-mush:
- wait PILGRED trade option to appear
- sell your partner
(Or better make a nice trap for humans - your partner do something like extracting spore in public and run to storage, humans go after him, you both stay online, when any human come to storage to kill him, he exit the room and you sell that human. Also you can do such trap even yourself with extracting spore on the bridge and waiting in Front Storage)
- transfer to commander
- return to Sol

On july 23, 2014
[8281354]

I assume by "sparkle" you mean an electric spike, though that's the cutest nickname I've never heard for it. XD It'd need to be expensive though, because it's mass sabotage as well as room damage.

I like the idea of picking up a spore from traps activated as a mush. One mush has to spend the AP to extract the spore and plant it, while the other has to get to the appropriate place before a human does. If it ends up being unbalanced, you could add a skill that allows you to save the spore instead of wasting it by triggering the trap, but I don't think it's needed.
On july 24, 2014
Flash

Might have been suggested before but here's my suggestion for more merchant trade deals:

  • Sell off an inactive crewmember in return for their respective level 1 skill as a magebook. (I had hoped this would be in since the new episode, correct me if I'm wrong).
  • Trade in two magebooks for one new random book (only from within the pool of choices that are available from Xyloph or at the start of the ship in the live version). Just a roulette to see if you'll get something more useful.
  • Trade away 4 magebooks for a book of your choice (again, only from within the pool of choices that are available from Xyloph or at the start of the ship in the live version).

Not intended to make the game easier but to somewhat alleviate the curse of inactivity (and griefing) as well as giving the crew (and the Mush) more choices but for a price. 4 skill books can be attained by not reading the starting book + the Chef and two other xyloph books if there are no inactives to trade off (or merchants buying).
On july 24, 2014
Necrodem

How can you imagine book "How become Last Humanity Hope in 7 days"? It is rediculous.

There is 16 magebooks in game: Astro, Bio, Botanic, Chef, Diplomat, FireFighter, IT, Logistic, Medic, Pilot, RE, Robotic, Shooter, Shrink, Sprinter, Teches. Well I see no useless books here and you?

Problem with not anoth skills can be solve by buying gold and get more exp in your char.

If trading was introduced to compensate inactive players than mage books would make much more sense instead of only some oxygen capsules/an exchange of a random project.
If a crew is lacking certain skills because the players with that skills are all inactive then the ship is doomed and mush has nothing to do...

On july 25, 2014
Flash

Another small suggestion:

Let the "Return to Sol" button on the command console require the input of both the Communications Officer and the Neron Administrator in addtion to the Commander (aka all the "heads" of the ship). So, say the Commander clicks the button that will let you return to Sol/Eden (with Pilgred finished), then Neron will make an announcement about it which encourages the Comms Officer and Neron Admin to both go to the command console and accept this course of action (by clicking the button again), which then takes the ship to the end of the game. The Hacker Kit should probably count as 1 vote if used.

There are two reasons for this suggestion. Firstly it makes the Mush players have to work a little bit for it when they want to do the 'rush pilgred and return to sol' strategy and secondly it reduces the chances of a human forcing himself and the ship back to Sol/Eden even if the crew wanted to continue (which happens quite often I've found).

Wait why am I even writing this here. Should be posting in the french forum

On july 25, 2014
Barlakopofai
Surgeon of the Pillhead

Fungiculture
High level mush skill
Secret Action
Create a tray for your spores to grow in.

  • For 3 and one plastic scrap, create a Mushroom Tray in the room you are in.

Mushroom Tray
Cannot be moved. Permanently hidden.

If any fruit reaches Level 3 decomposition in the same room as the tray, a spore will appear in the tray and can be collected by the owner.
Collecting a spore has a 50% of dirtying. It can be prevented by wearing the apron.
Searching the room will reveal the tray but only to the person who searched and only as long as they are in the room.
The tray cannot be dismantled or destroyed. It can however break. If the tray breaks, it loses all its spores and doesn't produce more until repaired.
On july 26, 2014
Dzanek

There must be a skill which allow Mush make public logs secret and revealed just by characters, such as Eleesha's "Observant" skill.
On july 26, 2014
crawlkill

The tutorial sucks. A lot of newbies go instantly idle. These two things in combination compound one another to create even more significant problems. To slightly mitigate the effect of instant idlers, Janice's tutorial should have her ending up in a dorm, NOT on the bridge, so that even if she idles, she can help the crew. Similarly, Raluca's tutorial should have her end in the engine room (a turret would be ideal but it would also be more confusing), so that if she insta-idles she won't just die within a day--that gives that newbie a chance to come back later and try to participate, at least.

Reworking the tutorial to be specific to characters in general would be helpful, but just changing it for those two could do a lot to make insta-idles less frustrating.
On july 26, 2014
Necrodem

crawlkill Tutorial make you understanding some game mechanic. Well if someone left on it... this doesn`t matter then tutorial "suck". It just mean then they do not like the game and prefere to leave it. It is OK.

And you can toss Janice(or anyone alse) in any room you wish. Just take Derek/Gioele or Stephen.

No - we do not need to rework tutorial. Yes - we need option to join ship with no first time players.
On july 26, 2014
crawlkill

Are you serious? The tutorial is terrible. It encourages people to try establishing connection with Sol with no awareness of the serious consequences of success before the whole crew is awake. It encourages people to use the worse-than-useless turrets. It encourages people to eat without warning them of the consequences of doing so. It encourages people to arbitrarily repair broken doors. None of those things are behaviors that should be suggested to newbies.

Throwing someone out of a room they shouldn't be in requires a) one of only three possible characters to have that skill, be active and be willing to do so and b) an inconceivable amount of :pa: if you want to actually get them somewhere useful.

And no, "join a ship with no first time players" would absolutely destroy the game. New players absolutely require experienced older players to guide them in order to have a good experience of the game. Older players need to be there to help them. The playerbase would gutter and die off without new players joining.

People don't go instantly idle because they "don't like the game." They've literally been on the game for less than five minutes by the time the tutorial completes. People go instantly idle because they're overwhelmed by the game, which in part is because of a tutorial that completely fails to give them clear advice on how to participate usefully. Imagine that compounded by having ships with no experienced players on them.
On july 26, 2014
crawlkill
Barlakopofai

Fungiculture
High level mush skill
Secret Action
Create a tray for your spores to grow in.


  • For 3 and one plastic scrap, create a Mushroom Tray in the room you are in.
    Mushroom Tray
    Cannot be moved. Permanently hidden.

If any fruit reaches Level 3 decomposition in the same room as the tray, a spore will appear in the tray and can be collected by the owner.
Collecting a spore has a 50% of dirtying. It can be prevented by wearing the apron.
Searching the room will reveal the tray but only to the person who searched and only as long as they are in the room.
The tray cannot be dismantled or destroyed. It can however break. If the tray breaks, it loses all its spores and doesn't produce more until repaired.

Now this is cool.
On july 26, 2014
Kyubey

Tutorial is terrible and need rework. Necrodem is right about tutorial is not the only reason, why people become idle - some don't even exit lab, but it does not make tutorial good.

As I see good tutorial, that a) sovles the problem of idles on ships b) teach people to do their job:

1) Tutorial takes place on empty "tutorial" ship. You are the only player there (but it may have some characters, to show how your skills like comfort work, but they are not players and do nothing)
2) Tutorial is different for different characters. It can show everyone some common actions, that are often asked from everyone - reseting research and projects, healing, but it should show the main job as well - for Jin Su - how to give missions, move the ship and do speeches for example.
3) Tutorial takes 2-3 cycles to finish. First of all it will show the game speed and the way how it's played. Second - it will leave 99% of first-timers who leave the game after "I burned all ap, waiting for cycle change so boring, don't want to play that" on tutorial.
4) After showing the game with human eyes, show it as mushes see it. To give at least few tips if a new player happen to be mush, and to give human at least basic advices not be spiked - like staying under cameras, watch others to become dirty and track strange activity.
On july 26, 2014
[7971963]

No matter how much we argue and insist that tutorial ships are required, the developers are fairly steadfast in not having them. (And they are. Really. This game needs a proper tutorial. The current one is beyond bad.)

Like it or not, Mush is balanced around having roughly four inactives and 2-4 players killed by various means. Adding a proper tutorial ship (which would probably drastically bump up retention rate, and make most of their paying community extremely happy!) would require most of the game be rebalanced.

I don't agree with it. I feel that the game should be balanced around a ship with at most two inactives (and two mush). However, MT has made their stance abundantly clear and they seem to have no intention of changing their position.

Quite frankly, if a real, proper, well-made tutorial was implemented, we would probably need a third alpha-mush to counter the massive decrease of inactive players and huge spike of gold players*.

*This is not hyperbole. I know at least six to ten people on my contacts list that refuse to buy gold unless they are on a ship that "stands a chance". MT would make a fair bit of money by implementing a proper tutorial. The fact that they don't is a loss for everyone.
On july 26, 2014
Kyubey

But there are so many ships with at least one idle mush, I have even been on ships with even both being idle. It's much greater hit to their team, then something like Janice idling in lab for humans. Newbie-mushes who do nothing or get caught very stupid is even more common. In ~15 ships of S4 I lost 3 if I'm not mistaken. And only 2 of them had mushes with skill.

* You don't have me in contact list, do you, Jamini? Then add me to the list of people who will buy gold only after the ship will prove it worth it

On july 28, 2014
sperbi

Alliedenemy what to do in that situation? hm, it is really difficult currently to do something against the tactic of occupying icarus bay. I have some ideas, but all of them are not very effective.

the ideal solution would be if a janice with diplomat is able to enter the icarus bay when a mush is leaving and is doing a ceasefire in icarus bay. then the mush who left icarus bay could be killed and the other mushes are not save anymore too since janice can leave the room at every time, when the other crew members are active... could also be possible without ceasefire ( then the person who is able to sneak into icarus bay should take care to not get turned or killed by mush-actually only possible if other humans are active and are killing the mush outside of icarus bay quickly and right after that the mushes in icarus bay) but it always requires high activity of some humans-not very easy...

another possibility woudl be to advance neron projects until you get bay upgrade, then you can enter the icarus bay again, but this coudl require some time and mush could sabotage it or convert 2 new people if the crew is not quick enough...

Last resort would be to advance pilgred a bit guard with almost all people front corridor, let the commander (if the commander is a human) be at bridge, and the most important people shoudl get all oxygen capsules, so a mush is suffocating first, then kill the other mushes and return to sol after that.
But in every scenario it is very difficult for humans to win and it requires activity above average.

They wreck the game completely. The more the structure of the game can diminish the harm they do by taking out completely pivotal skills, the better. Every time a grand inactif dies and I lose morale to it, I just ask myself...why? Why did I have to be punished because that person who didn't do a thing all ship joined my ship?

On august 23, 2014
Irishpolak

I've searched all over and can't find a discussion about this, but I'm sure one exists somewhere.

I've recently started playing Die 2 Nite more frequently, and something from there I would like to see implemented into mush is some sort of delay on ships starting. We've already got a delay on the apron and the mush sample, but maybe there could be delays on everything prior to mush selection. Hunters shooting, AP gain on cycle change, morale loss, dismantling, research and NERON, taking out patrol ships, maybe even moving items? This way it would remove any confusion over "neutral play", and everyone would be in the same boat after mush selection, no more ships dropping down to 70-80 hull because pilots are the last to join up or people hoarding any items before mush selection just to make it easier for whatever team they're on. Granted, I seem to recall hearing that MT wants to keep certain things the way they are, so I may be just dreaming up random nonsense here.

On august 23, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?
CwovictorIf the devolpers didn't want us to food test, they wouldn't make it so the mush are instanly full.

This isn't the place for yet another debate on food tests, but briefly : no, food tests are not intended by the developers. They have made it clear, through numerous updates and fixes, that they don't want mush tests to be possible. In fact, at the very beginning, the Mush could eat as much as they wanted without ever being full. The current limitation was introduced not to allow food tests, but to prevent Mush from depriving the humans from food too easily. They hadn't anticipated that it would be used for Mush tests, and so far, they haven't prevented this particular test (but have made lots of other tests impossible).
On august 24, 2014
npfan
PeanutzThey hadn't anticipated that it would be used for Mush tests, and so far, they haven't prevented this particular test (but have made lots of other tests impossible).

They also don't allow Mush to get sick, or get the same effects from eating, or be able to starve, or have morale work the same as humans, or use the Spore Sucker. If the developers didn't intend to have some game-mechanical way to find out if someone is a Mush or not, they don't exactly have a great track record.

On august 24, 2014
crawlkill

On august 29, 2014
Kyubey

As you begin speaking about spacesuits, here some ideas of giving them more important role for both mush and humans, while keeping logic like "if you are in spacesuit, then you cannot get dirty".

- You don't wear spacesuit just with picking it up. If you picked it up - then you just holding it, to put it on you should do an action "Put on" while holding spacesuit for 1ap. To take off - "Take off" action, also for 1ap.
- When you put on a spacesuit your character model is replaced with spacesuit
- You cannot get dirty, while wearing spacesuit
- If there is somebody in the room with you or camera, then they see who are you anyway
- If there is nobody in the room, every public log about you will be replaced by "Somebody". Like "Somebody entered the room, somebody picked up hackers kit"
- Wearing a spacesuit will reduce chance of some events of the planets like Fatigue in High/Low tempetures or Illnesses in Swamps when it's logical
- Accidents on the planets, damage from Combat events on the planet or being attacked with weapons on the ship, while wearing a spacesuit can get it broken
- If a mush sabotage a spacesuit, broken status is not visiable to humans and they don't have option ot repair it. They can use a new "Check spacesuit" action on a spacesuit they are holding to reveal broken status. Drones will try to repair broken spacesuits anyway.
- Wearing a broken spacesuit on planet without O2 will cost you 1 hp / zone, wearing broken spacesuit after ejecting from patrol ship will cost you 3-5 hp instantly and you will die on cycle change, also you will die with broken spacesuit on planet without O2 on cycle change, if you got MIA
- Others don't see if you are dirty, while you are wearing a spacesuit
- You cannot do some actions, while wearing a spacesuit - eating, working in lab, working in nexus, do planet analize or anything in comms, take shower, hug the cat....
- Mush cannot do some of their actions while wearing spacesuit like extracting spores, using green jelly.... when it's not logical by discription
- Wearing spacesuit give some chance (for example like 50%) to absorb 1 point of damage
- If you got spored by direct spiking or trap this spore will not be added to your spore number, until you try to take off a spacesuit

On august 30, 2014
npfan

New option for Biologists, Medics, Nurses, and Polyvalents:
Prescription
Costs 1 AP
Privacy Level: Invisible
Allows someone on the ship to consume a pill. The prescription is sent to the player in the same tab as missions, announcements, etc. A person with the Prescription does not need a prescription to consume a pill. Mush do not need a prescription to consume a pill. No one else may eat a pill without a prescription. Someone with Prescription may send a prescription to someone else that already has Prescription or is Mush. No one can eat more than one pill in the same cycle. If someone with a prescription has not eaten the pill prescribed yet, he or she may reject the prescription. The AP used to prescribe will not be returned. A pill that is actively prescribed cannot be consumed by anyone except the person with the prescription. A prescription cannot be made to someone who is Super Inactive. Any active prescriptions sent to someone that later becomes Super Inactive or dead are automatically rejected. Any active prescriptions sent to someone that later is converted to Mush or takes a skill with Prescription stay active.

On september 1, 2014
[8480168]

Kicking inactive players out of rooms should be controllable instead of random pushing around, so that you can choose the room, where you want to put that player into.

For example, If you click on a character now, there is the option Kick Them Out. This option could be Kick them into (Roomname), so that we can choose.

There are way too many inactive players in the game and this is the only good way, to get rid of this problem. It´s hard enough to survive with so many inactive players and this makes it not really better, because this can be an incredible waste of AP. I spent 20 AP on my last ship to push 1 character into front storage and i started in Front Corridor. With half of the crew inactive, it takes some players for that action. Some days wasted only because of inactivity and lack control over this action and the chances of survival get even worse with that. In my opinion this is one of the mayor issues in the game and i totally miss an option like in Die2Nite or similar, where you can join advanced cities.

On september 6, 2014
Sagittaeri

I was just casually mentioning this to someone in IRC, and then realised it's not a bad idea.

Eleesha's Level 6 skill: Eavesdropper

For 2 APs, user can see a snippet of a random currently-open Private Message in the ship. The number of messages in the snippet shown should be the sum of the user's APs and MPs before skill is used (since eavesdropping requires a lot of waiting). Speaker names in the messages should be aliased to "A", "B", "C", etc...otherwise it'll be overpowered against the mush.

On september 7, 2014
tinkrr

I have an add-on idea for the pregnant status.

Pregnant >> Mother

If a female crew member is pregnant for a specific amount of days (the birth can take place on any cycle within that day), she will give birth, her pregnant status becoming "mother" after the process. The baby will then grant all crew members a morale point at the start of a new day, but will require to be taken care of (this will cost AP). If the baby somehow dies, all crew members will lose 4 morale (similar to how Raluca loses morale if Schrödinger dies).

There will be glory points as well, of course!
On september 7, 2014
Cwovictor
tinkrr

I have an add-on idea for the pregnant status.

Pregnant >> Mother

If a female crew member is pregnant for a specific amount of days (the birth can take place on any cycle within that day), she will give birth, her pregnant status becoming "mother" after the process. The baby will then grant all crew members a morale point at the start of a new day, but will require to be taken care of (this will cost AP). If the baby somehow dies, all crew members will lose 4 morale (similar to how Raluca loses morale if Schrödinger dies).

On september 8, 2014
SummerMcLovin
tinkrrWe can always pretend babies develop faster in space, though. After all, the Daedalus is already traveling at the speed of light. Maybe there can be side effects.

Being in space would probably slow the development but since they have decent food it'd probably be as normal. Artificial gravity would probably avoid the difficulty in recognising the start of labour and the actual birth, perhaps similar to how astronauts struggle to recognise when they need to get some of their bodily functions done.
The Daedalus only travels at relativistic/hyperspace speeds when PILGRED is repaired (and is only used to get to Sol or Eden), but even if it was it'd only distort time for those outside the ship - as far as the crew is concerned it'll still be a term of about 9 months.

Not particularly meaning to tear your idea to pieces, just bringing some science to the proceedings

On september 8, 2014
horusboyd
tinkrrAww... I find Schrödinger to be a rather adorable addition to the ship. Guess cats just aren't your thing. <:

He is and I love him! But imagine if there were two. Cats reproduce 2 - 3 times a year. If you don't chuck your little kittens out of the airlock regularly, there will be about 80 million Schrödingers after ten years (the critical mass of Schrödingers, before they fuse into one metabeing that may or may not exist, be a cat, or live in hyperspace projecting himself into our perceived dimensions).
Now, we're looking at a pregnant human player giving birth after a week or so (I'm making up this value, but it seems reasonable), meaning time passes about 36 times faster aboard the Daedalus. That means the critical mass of Schrödingers would be reached after about 13 weeks of playtime. I don't know if any ship has ever gone on for so long, but do you really want to risk finding out if Metaschrödinger is dead or alive?

Fire Supression System

Fire Supression System

Some random project:

Automated Defense System
By rewiring the cutting edge Thingumatron 3000 Teslatron Turrets to Neron's neural network we should be able to not only give Neron a way to release some steam but also to help us cope with the increasing Hunter problem. Score!

  • Each functioning turret on the Daedalus has a 15% chance to fire one shot each cycle at the base accuracy efficiency of 30%.
  • As the turrets are hooked up to Neron directly, each currently completed Nexus Project will increase the base accuracy of the shots by 1% (additive). Does not work for manual targeting.
  • Does not target non-combat vessels unless DMZ CorePeace has been disabled.

On september 25, 2014
Gallade

Mush skill: Morph Flesh
Description: "As humans would put it, the next best thing to having no weakness is to show none. You can improvise patches of artificial healthy skin to cover (or show) your most suspicious or worrying wounds."
Effect: Adds an "Apparent HP" bar to your regular HP bar. The Apparent HP can be adjusted manually to any number between 1 and 14, and will affect whether or not you can be healed with a Medkit and use Bandages. It will also go down from anything that would affect a human, such as being hit, injured by accidents and so on, but will not go down when showering.
When hit with a Natamy Rifle, the "Real" HP will take 6-13 damage, but the "Apparent" HP will only take 2-4 as a human would.

Beware though, as when your Apparent HP fall to zero, a message ("In spite of [his/her] wounds, [character] still seems to be hanging on to life.) will give away that your wounds are starting to look a bit too good to be true. This could be mitigated by a new mechanic (perhaps give a tiny (say, 10%), once-per-ship chance to everyone to stay with 1 HP when combat damage would kill them), but it's still going to be hard explaining such a "stroke of luck"

Strategic application: The most obvious use is to help fly "under the radar" of crew mates who are tracking everyone's HP to find Mush. Setting it to maximum after taking a shower will make it look so that you didn't lose any Health, and while this isn't enough to clear your name yet thanks to Splashproof, it can avoid some suspicion when the rest of the crew is busy with other business.

By claiming to have taken damage (or more damage than you did) in "accidents", or after a fight, you can force the crew to waste AP on healing you and/or relocate the Medkit through the ship, expecially if you're a character that works in a space far from the common areas.

The most useful application, though, is to simulate starving damage: by "forgetting" to eat for three days and pretending to take damage, you can appear human, expecially if you stay in a crowded area (like the shower-less dorm) and thus leave no other option as to what could have hurt you.

Careless application of the skill, though, wil be counterproductive since humans can and will get suspicious if one of their crewmates appears unusually "accident prone"...
On september 25, 2014
DarkTheRaven

Here's 2 more ideas:

1. Airlock (NERON Project) (located in Front storage)
Description: this little room leads outside... probably shouldnt open it
Effects: Crew members are able to put items (and crew members) in the airlock and with permission from the commander (can be opened directly from the airlock, or from the command terminal) jettison unwanted objects and crew members into the cold grasp of space. To push crew members into the airlock use a wrestler/solid

2. Post-its can actually be posted on items giving it an extra description when examined

Mush skill:The Mole

Description: "It's funny how those Hunters can barely find such a big ship in a sector that's swarming with them. A little tune-up to your walkie-talkie could send them a nudge in the right direction...

Effect: For 2 AP and one Spore, you can "Tip off Hunters".

-The action is Covert. If used in a room with a camera, it will reveal the log:

[character] looks around shiftily, and hastily murmurs something into his/her Walkie Talkie.

-When used, in 2-4 Cycles a wave of Hunters will appear. The number and type of Hunters will depend on the Day in which it was used. Using this skill several times in the same cycle will summon more Hunters.

-If the Mush with this skill is wearing a Spacesuit or piloting a Patroller or the Pasiphae at the time the Daedalus is destroyed, they will gain additional , and the cause of death will be replaced with "Rescued from the wreckage by SDF Hunters"

-Hunters will not shoot at a patroller piloted by a Mole if it's outside at cycle change. Also, they will leave the Daedalus with only 1 Armor point if they would destroy a ship with a Mole which isn't wearing a Spacesuit, but only once. They will destroy the ship at the next cycle change. Asteroids will still destroy the ship.

On september 26, 2014
Gallade

New upgrade: Flak automation
Bonus from: Robotics Expert and Shooter
Effect: A new interactive object, Targeting computer, is added in each turret. At the beginning of every cycle (but after hunters appear), if the Daedalus is engaged in combat with Hunters, each turret with a functional Targeting Computer will fire once against a random target with a medium-low accuracy (40%?)

The Automation can be turned on or off from the NERON BIOS Terminal. When active, the turrets regenerate one less charge per cycle.

Anyone can upgrade the Targeting Computers for one Scrap Metal and four AP (Robotics Expert only need two, Technicians can use one of their Repair Points) like so:

Retargeting: The turret will shoot twice, unless there is only one charge left.
Blaster Tune-Up: The turret will inflict more damage on automatic shots
CPU Optimization:The turret will regenerate one extra charge per cycle (negating the penalty for staying active)
Accuracy Algorhythm: Greatly increases the Turret's accuracy

On september 27, 2014
Kyubey

New game ending - assault on CENTAURI

After comm manager has decoded at least 5 rebel bases a new announcement appears:
NERONInalizing rebel transmisions discovered a possibility for Daedalus assault team to make a difference in a war for CENTAURI. New route was added to commander terminal.

Now, if PILGRED is online, commander will see a new button "Go to CENTAURI"
If he press the button, Daedalus will begin moving (with animation of stars flying like 5 times faster then regular movement speed, to show difference between PILGRED and emergency reactor).
On the beginning of next cycle, you will arrive to the CENTAURI orbit (ye, should take weeks or months...).

What will change after arriving on orbit:
- Commnader terminal becomes broken and cannot be repaired (so you cannot use PILGRED anymore, you cannot leave the orbit)
- All hunters of any type were overrun
- But every cycle huge waves (20-30 of hunters of all types) will arrive

Planet you are orbiting always has 20 zones. 1 is always O2, 14 of them are random zones of any type, like on any planet, 5 are "Mush command center".
While having little time, being attack by hunters your team should pass 5 "Mush command centers" zones. When they are destroyed - the game ends with a message "You came to CENTAURI and gave a new hope to win the war for sector, but how it ended is another story".

Mush command center
Differences:
- Diplomat cannot prevent combats here
- Natami rifle gives +4 combat strength, instead of +1
- Even if you died during that zone, it counts as destoyed as well - like there were no survivors there.

10% - Combat with mush
You were expecting resistance, but you never thought it could be so strong. They have machine guns, rocket launchers and heavy plasma cannons. It will be very difficult. Combat event with strenght of 25.
20% - Mush trap
You crushed enemy resistance easily...too easily. When you entered a building you realized, it was just a trap to turn you to new mushes.
30% - Accident
Battle went very well, until X took a baslter shoot in the shoulder. At least it was the only injury.
40% - Combat with mush
You took possitions around building, unfortunatly you were discovered by enemies. Combat event with strenght of 15.

Diffences in glory and endscreens:
If all 5 centers were destoyed it's always human victory, even if some mushes are still alive (great job helping humans to crush your army, you infiltration was not worth it)
+8 glory for every human when he arrives to CENTAURI
+2 glory for every member of expo in "Mush command center" zone
+3 glory for every minor research (like always)
+6 glory for every major research (like always)
+16 glory for RFS (like always)
+4 glory for every person with Solid, Shooter, Wrestler or Pilot skills alive (we will need skilled soldiers)
+2 glory for projects/research for combat (Armored Corridors, Blaster Gun, Launch Propulsion System, Plasma Shield, Rerouted Charges, Teslatron Reservoir, Trail Minimizer, Meridon Scrambler, Natamy Rifle, Tesla SUP2X)
+16 glory if you had passed all 5 centers
+20 mush glory for every mush on the ship, if it was destoyed in CENTAURI sector

Why I had idea like that:
To make some projects, items and skills useful, while now they are not important. Things that will help a lot:
Items: Natami. Machine gun, Rocket Launcher, more grenades, more blaster from traders
Projects: Large Bay Upgrade
Skills: Shooter

Gallade

On september 28, 2014
[7950824]

Have you tried dropping your talkie, making sure your PMs are all closed (rarely, when you drop your talkie, 1 or more stay open until you move or close them, not sure why), then click on someone in the room with you and see if you have a 'whisper' option? There's two reasons why this could fail; the other person might have 3 PM channels already, or you or they could have an injury that prevents communication. Otherwise, I believe you can whisper to anyone in the same room with you no matter if you or they have a talkie, just have to click on them first.

If they leave the room before they read your message, the PM closes, there's a few other tricks that can mess up or help this, but that's the basic idea of 'whisper'. I've mostly used whispers for Expos to planets where we all had to drop talkies, but needed to coordinate before launch.
On september 28, 2014
Kyubey

Ever seen a private conversation with someone ending with "Left the room without a walkie talkie"? Yes, all private channels disappear when you drop your walkie talkie and you can't make any more, unless you're Paola or on the bridge.
When you drop your walkie, all privite chats with people, who are not in the same room with you, close. You can use another player walkie to speak in your privite chat you both are in it.
Example:
You in room with Frieda. Paola, Chun and KT (room is not bridge, you are not comm manager)
You have privite chats with:
1) KT. Jin Su
2) Frieda, Paola
3) Gioele
You drop walkie - only chat 3 closes. You still can speak with Frieda and Paola, you still can speak with KT and even with Jin Su, thanks to KT in room.
If KT leaves - you will be disconnected from chat 1.
If both Frieda and Paola leave on same time - from chat 2.
If you leave room yourself - everything will close.
On september 28, 2014
Gallade

New Human skill: Strong-arm.

- +1 damage to unarmed attacks, similar to Solid
- New action, Sequester, cost 1 AP, which allows to take a (non-personal) item from the target, and has a lower accuracy (45%) compared to Kick Off:
[name] casually walks up to [name]...and suddenly gives them a forceful shove! While [name] is trying to regain their balance, [name] snatches the [item] from their grip.
- If the target has no items that can be taken, they take unarmed damage instead:
[name] casually walks up to [name]...and suddenly gives them a forceful shove! [name] tumbles backward and knocks their head hard on the ground
- New action, Bodycheck, available for 3 AP, which puts the target in a Bodyblocked status. Bodyblocked people:
- Are easier to hit with all attacks (similar to being Inactive)
- Can still talk on their Walkie-Talkie
- Have most actions disabled and can't leave the room. They can attack their aggressor hand-to-hand, but can't use weapons or attack anyone else in the room.
- Have the action available, Struggle Free, to rid themselves of the blocking. This action costs the blocker's HP divided by the victim's HP, rounded uo, from a minimum of 1 to a maximum of 4. For instance, a player with 10 HP blocking one with 6 will require 2 AP to struggle free.
- The blocker also can't do anything else except Release, which is an action that consumes no AP.

On september 29, 2014
Gallade

The SDF may try to board the Daedalus!
-Boarding Pod: 16 Armor. If not destroyed or evaded within 4 cycles it will board the Daedalus, spawning a SDF Soldier in one of the four bays.
--SDF Soldier: 6 , will be carrying a Knife or a Blaster and a Bandage. At the end of each cycle, will perform one action. In order of priority:
-Shoot a crew member. Will not open fire on Mush, and will prioritize humans with no/less spores on them
If there are no human targets in the room, he will perform one of
-Attempt to sabotage equipment in the room
-Booby-trap the room
-Use his Bandage if he's been hurt
After that, he will move to another room
-Carrier: 35 Armor. If not destroyed or evaded within 5 cycles it will board the Daedalus, spawning two SDF Soldiers and either a SDF Elite or a Berserker
-SDF Elite: 14 ,Has one of: Lizaro Jungle, Rocket Launcher, Knife+Plastenite Armor. Also has a Medkit which he may use on his allies or Mush crewmates. Is able to attack and perform another action in the same cycle.
-Berserker: A mutated Mush. 16 and all damage taken reduced by 1. Will only attack or move to seek a new target.Occasionally it will hit the walls, making the Daedalus lose hull integrity.

On september 30, 2014
Gallade

New ability: Sniper
-When equipping a firearm, a Sniper may use the action Peek on a door to view the room on the other side (provided that the room isn't broken), and then target any person in it, using 2 AP or one Shooter point (if they also have the Shooter skill) to fire. This will generate a log in either room as long as there is a camera or a witness. Pacifist restriction will not apply for room the victim is in (but will apply for the shooter). Ian can be shot from an adjacent room for only 2 AP, but if you're in a room with Ian you will spend 4 AP to snipe people in other rooms. Plus, there is a chance that the shot will go wild and hit another person or break equipment in the room.

As an added bonus, characters with this skill will have a doubled base chance (60%) of hitting a target when firing a turret.

A skill that will make it easier to target enemies without giving away your position, although the fact you have the skill will be a dead giveaway that it was you if the victim isn't alone. It will also make it easier for both Mush to get rid of Ian, and for Humans to get rid of a Mush Ian or a Mush taking covering behind Ian's protection if you don't have a character capable of kicking one of them out of the room.

Oh, and will finally give the goddamn turrets some use besides being Raluca's lone shack.

[7947444]

Idea 1:
I’d like the ability when selecting my character that would allow me to volunteer to be mush. While right now you have a 6.6% chance to be mush, being a volunteer might bump that to a 10% chance at the expense of non-volunteers. Of course, if everyone volunteers you would drop back down to 6.6% again. I’ve dumped tons of XP into my mush skills. I’d like to be able to at least have a slightly better chance at becoming one.

Idea 2:
Mush Skill: Human digestive Track
You conversion to becoming a mush had complications and you were never fully converted. You maintain a normal human eating requirements and gain satisfaction/full status. Allowed to eat two or more items pending satisfaction requirements. Bad news, you’re subject to pesky starvation requirements that humans have.

Idea 3:
Mush Skill: Feign Illness
You have the ability to feign a random illness. You occur none of the side effects of said illness, but your acting abilities allow you to put on a remarkably believable show…. Maybe even worthy of Oscar.

Idea 4:
Fuel in jerry cans should be able to be dropped anywhere. Rooms with jerry cans laying around increase potential of room fires… but at least you can set them down right?
On october 2, 2014
Gallade

Idea 2: Oh, Riiiiight, we REALLY needed Silver Mush capable of tearing through an entire ship with AP pill+2 Bananas+However many coffees they can stash+Ration+Phagocyting their own spores.

Idea 3: Not much useful per se, Mush can already feign catching an illness simply by catching it before they're converted or Transferring into a sick crewmate.

Idea 4: Fuel costs nothing but MP to move. Griefer or Mush with Sprinter or Scooter takes all the fuel, dumps it in the Engine Room, then starts/waits for a fire to start, say goodbye to any hope of winning the game.

On october 4, 2014
Gallade

New Mush skill: Tamper
Description: Computers are the most vulnerable system of all...change a 0 with an 1, and all sorts of things can happen...

For 2 AP and a Spore, a Mush can access a console and change the following things:
-Planet Scanner: Change the appearance of one zone on the currently displayed planet. "No guys, it's totally not full of volcanoes, look, there's a lovely Orchard!"
-Comms Center: Broadcast taunting messages, increasing the odds of encountering Hunters and decreasing those of meeting merchants. Close the channel to a Rebel Base, making it shut down the signal prematurely.
-MycoScan: Set it so that it always displays the same number.
-MycoAlarm: Make it go off at random times whenever an action is performed
-Surgery Pod: Make it go haywire, halving the chances of surgeries being successful.
-NERON's Core and Research Table: Skew the progress towards the lower end of the expected range, lowering the overall efficiency.
-Control Panel:Causes room shaking, random breakages, fire or steel plate accident on next cycle, number and gravity of incidents increase in later days.

On october 9, 2014
Gallade

Wait, even better, I have a big idea that would help a lot make the whole Mush issue more balanced.

In Die2Nite, Ghouls aren't just encouraged to hamper the town by eating its denizens: they HAVE to, or they die of starvation from human flesh.

Here, how about this system:
-Mush Morale isn't always maxed anymore, and can't be replenished normally (by doing it, Shrink, Rebel bases etcetera)
-It goes down at the pace of 2 per day for Alphas, 1 for Betas.
-It goes UP every time the Mush successfully does something that helps the Mush team: infecting a human, sabotaging equipment, setting up a booby trap, using a Mush skill, attacking a human, hiding inportant items such as armor, apron or Mush Sample etc.
-It goes down every time you do something that is beneficial to the Human team: doing anti-Mush research, fixing equipment, healing/comforting/giving a speech, attacking a fellow Mush, destroying Hunters and so on. The Shrink and Logistic Expert passive skills don't count.
-When it reaches zero, at the end of a cycle the Mush in your body takes it as you betraying the Mush cause, kills you instantly and transfers to one of the other humans aboard, giving priority to those already infected with spores. The death is still reported as a normal suicide, and the crew bar will show a dead human (since the Mush has abandoned their body).

It would resolve some issues with the game, namely:
-Alpha Mush such as Gioele that have almost only skills that are detrimental or lost as Mush and as such are easy to be found out: they just have to hold out until their Mush jumps to someone else. Will still give them the short end of the stick since they'll die anyway, but at least it won't mean an instant Human victory.
-Inactive Mush. Instead of giving the crew the easy way of letting all inactives starve or suicide and then kill the one that didn't, they will have to ACTIVELY seek out inactive Mush (and make use of the Natamy), or there will be a chance that the parasite will pass on to an active member...
-Prevent the Mush playstyle of either going anti-game by doing everything a human would do for no good reason other than mantaining a Façade without actually doing anything Mushy, or wait it out until the ship is destroyed.
On october 9, 2014
Gallade

Also, when there are at least 4 Mush on board, Mush morale stops dropping. By then, you have enough manpower...pardon, Mushroompower, to take over the ship or infect Sol.
On october 9, 2014
SummerMcLovin

Seems to be rather forceful about the opinion that all Mush must actively and dangerously further the Mush goal with everything they do. There are many different ways to take down a ship and not all of them have to be overtly doing so. A lot of the stuff you've listed as positive Mush actions are the sort of tutorial tips that get new players immediately killed after doing them. "Using a Mush skill" might be fine and dandy when you have lots of options, but what about that first-time Mush who only has Phagocyte? Hardly furthers the Mush cause if they are sitting cannibalising their own spore-sac.

You seem pretty pissed about inactive or sneaky Mush, but going by your supposed opinion that "for the team is always best" you're actually encouraging them to suicide since that not only takes away one active crew member, it also takes out an active human and adds them to the Mush team. The humans are punished twice, purely for the poor play of their supposed enemy.

Even if only one Mush makes it back to Sol, they have a "link to the hive mind" or whatever with likely millions of other Mush when they get there - no need to have four of them in the immediate vicinity.

On october 22, 2014
Gallade

On october 22, 2014
TeufelsAdvokat

In fact there are no ifs, Gallade:

Level 1 pilot with full AP-bar, carrying 2 spores and Phagocyte(yeah, that's a mush level one skill ) can inflict more than 50 damage within minutes.

Don't believe me? Here some maths:

12 AP + 8 AP= 20 AP.
4 AP to start and land the first, 2 AP to start the second patroller. Makes 14 shots at the Daedalus.
Pilots accuracy is 80%, patrollers do 3-6 damage(without upgrades, correct me, if I'm wrong, average 4,5)

14*0,8*4,5 = 50,4
Actually it's more, since the accuracy increases, if a shot fails. However it's good to measure the damage, a single pilot can easily inflict.

On october 22, 2014
Gallade

He suggested that a Paranoid character carrying a camera can reveal Covert actions even if there is not a camera installed, basically making them a moving camera-guy. While it would have some uses, it would only catch inexperienced Mush off-guard, everyone else would just treat Gioele as a camera and avoid spiking around him.
On october 22, 2014
Gallade
TeufelsAdvokat

In fact there are no ifs, Gallade:

Level 1 pilot with full AP-bar, carrying 2 spores and Phagocyte(yeah, that's a mush level one skill ) can inflict more than 50 damage within minutes.

Don't believe me? Here some maths:

12 AP + 8 AP= 20 AP.
4 AP to start and land the first, 2 AP to start the second patroller. Makes 14 shots at the Daedalus.
Pilots accuracy is 80%, patrollers do 3-6 damage(without upgrades, correct me, if I'm wrong, average 4,5)

14*0,8*4,5 = 50,4
Actually it's more, since the accuracy increases, if a shot fails. However it's good to measure the damage, a single pilot can easily inflict.

It's still a valid suggestion, even though it needs some tweaking. Perhaps change the damage against the Daedalus to 1-3, like a regular Hunter? Would make sense that a capital ship like the Daedalus, even if not built for combat, would take less damage than a disposable fighting drone. 14 shots (Let's say that on average 11 of them land) would do on average 22 damage, which isn't irreparable unless the human pilots are really sleeping on the job (in that case it just anticipates an eventual death by hunter horde). It's not uncommon to see ships that have already lost about 20 hull from hunters before Mush selection, so. And about destroying other Patroller...well, anyone who goes afk while piloting outside is pretty much asking for disaster, unless they're waiting to be pulled in by Magnetic Net.

On october 22, 2014
Gallade

Hmm, how about a riot shield-like item? It's a heavy item, as long as you are holding it, you have permanent Guardian status, and combat damage against you takes off AP instead of HP. You automatically drop it when your AP reaches zero, and has a cumulative chance of breaking every time it blocks damage.

Good for when you want to survive at any cost, even if it means sacrificing your productivity on the long run.

And yes, it will make Mush Ian even more broken, thanks for caring.

On october 23, 2014
SummerMcLovin

I was considering yesterday that you could either open up the Medic skill a bit (i.e. give it to Chun) but remove the research bonus. That stops Finola (when she eventually returns) from having a double bonus, sure, but it also means that Biologist isn't a worthless Bronze choice for her. You get to choose between being a Medic-style Doctor to heal people and an Academic-style Doctor working on your research theses. That may also take care of the imbalance against the Mush that led to her being removed from some (all, in our current case) ships.

If Chun isn't getting Medic (perhaps instead of Nurse), buff Nurse so it is more than just some free actions. Maybe buff Nurse regardless of whether Chun gets Medic or not. I don't know if I suggested it before (this is an old idea) but perhaps any healing actions in the room with her (perhaps not including her own) do +1 or +2 health restored, along with the free actions.
RL Nurses can do plenty of patient care in a hospital, but they also help doctors with the more complicated stuff; both are captured in the suggested two effects of the skill.

On october 25, 2014
DarkTheRaven

NERON PROJECT

Life support system

Description: From the makers of CryoModule(TM): Using this handy piece of technology you can... How to say force someone to live, it will keep them fed and healthy within reasonable error. (Please note LifeSupport(TM) and its affiliates are not responsible for any injuries or deaths that occur using LifeSupport(TM) be sure to always read and follow the manual)

Effects: Once completed this project will spawn a life support module in the med lab, someone may enter it willingly, or once inactive can be forced in for 2AP by a solid/wrestler, while inside a character cannot be killed by starvation or morale loss (Anesthetics in the future do some crazy things, something about rainbows and unicorns) The system will also heal 3 per day. It also has a 10% chance of healing injuries every 4 cycles

Occupants may be forcefully ejected by the commander, there is a 35% chance that exiting the life support module will give injuries, being forced into the life support module will yield a 60% chance of sustaining injuries after entering, being ejected by the commander will not yield any injury but will take 1 cycle to safely eject the player

While inside the cryo module a player will gain the sleeping bonus, they may try to forcefully eject themselves for 3AP this yields an 80% chance of injury if successful (maybe you shouldnt have yanked those tubes out) If an electrical spike or sabotaging mush damage the life support module, the crew member inside will be ejected with a 50% chance of injury

While in the life support module items will be stored in an attached locker which can also be opened by the captain, upon exiting the support system all items are immediately retrieved, communications are limited to those within the room thanks to a useful 2 way conversation speaker

Upon using the Life support system there is a 5% chance every day the user dies displaying the death log: Death registered: Character, cause: unknown medical error and a room log displaying All seemed to be going well for (Crew member inside support) until a robotic arm went haywire and stabbed a scalpel into their heart

Every cycle there is a 10% chance that something goes wrong and causes the occupant to take 2 of damage

While inside the support module, crew members HP and Morale may not be affected by outside sources (ie rebel bases, steel plates, shrinks)

If a crew member with a title enters the life support system the title is passed off to the next in line

Project bonus efficiency: Technician, Medic

I think i have some ideas to reduce the number of inactive player.

Instead of instantly start the game players has to travel in a small groups to the daedalus and play a kind of prolog story. It should be quiet easy to manage even for a single player, but they can earn little bonuses (like a food ration or o2 or anothe bonus) or avoide a malus by doing some quests to make this phase of the gae more interesting. Maybe the difficulty of the rolog varies with the activity of the players to stay a little bit challanging.
But to arrive on a ship everybody has to perform some action to initiate his personal journey to the daedalus:
After 2 or 3 days everybody, who has completed his nesecary actions, will be transfered to the daedalus, a countdown starts and at the end of the countdown all available active players will be assembled to complete crews. some will have to wait a little bit longer but that´s far better than starting on an inactive ship.

Further character choosing could be changed. Everybody (gold-account?) can choose freely who he wants to play but the game shows a warning for characters to many players want to play.(= long time waiting for a new ship when finished.

On december 7, 2014
lplplplp55

On december 7, 2014
Pave

Well if ship-launching would be any similar or least consistently-regular as in Die2Nite, that would would already a huge improvement.

Related previous posts of mine:
Gather current bugs here
Why I don't pay for Gold Mode

Yes, there would be a chance of having "stacked"-ships if there was only a single ship being filled at the time; that would be a "player"-problem. But considering it would improve generally the ship filling itself to be more "regular", the benefits simply overweight this "minimal"-problem, at least in my opinion.

As far as I have understood, Die2Nite actually fills the towns so that it puts non-Hero-players automatically to almost-filled towns, and then afterwards starts filling the next-almost-filled town.
This is not case with Mush which can simply start a new ship (of supposedly 4) right as soon as the previous one has filled. And since this is purely "RNG" /luck-based, it possible to have a newer ship being filled much earlier than the older ones.

Sure, we necessarily wouldn't need to identical system of "game starts only once ship is full" as in Die2Nite; we already have neutral-play semi-implemented.
But in addition all "anomalies"/ hazards and other especially missable-events (e.g. Rebel-bases) should be disabled / shouldn't be counting until ship is filled to completely: I personally wouldn't care if this would completely remove the "immersion"; it's for the benefit of players wanting actually "fair"-start
(e.g. First of crew, who is non-pilot, wakes up on Day 2 Cycle 8 to find ~10-hunters and hull at less than 40-units (there are no announcements recorded prior the "gravity simulation equipment activation", for those who didn't know)).


Regardless if this is "fault" of casting system or not, the current ship-filling system is simply unacceptable / large bug (because there has been no official "works as intended"-announcement so far), especially to at least a one who is also paying to play this game...
On december 8, 2014
Astrid

Pave Waiting 1-2 days in front of a black screen is not realy better.

With my idea people would have the opportunity to do something without affecting the story on the daedalus directly and by the way they can prove to be active players.
Getting some bonus material like scrap, plastic, maybe a piece of equipment or even a magebook from time to time by performing more difficult task during the prolog would give players the posibility to take some influence.

Mush status should be applied on th first day on the shuttle, but mush shouldn´t be able to extract spores or not more than 1 spore during the prolog.
Reason: if a player refuses to play mush he would get inactive on the daedalus anyway.

Necrodem try to stay constructive.
On december 8, 2014
Pave
AstridtPave Waiting 1-2 days in front of a black screen is not really better.

But I have mentioned having a single ship being filled-up instead of several, haven't I? Because currently the situation is this: We have pretty unknown / well-hidden amount of ships being filled illogically and irregularly, which therefore "postpones the gameplay" if not downright "scales all the odds against (human-)players..

Though the prologue-game-idea nice too, we would need more immediate and less coding-time-requiring solutions at the moment, which of my suggestions the reduction of the amount of "stand-by" ships would be be more than fitting at the moment.
However, some sort of "warm-up"-time which allows chat and such, so people wouldn't need to "stare at black screen for 1 or more days", could a nice addition too before further possible prologue-chapters / cargo-loading-step.

On december 11, 2014
[8281990]

I agree, due to the easy way you can grab titles. It can be used in an interesting way for everyone, but it can also be too big a help to the mush. Maybe if it cost 2 spores instead...?

I recently participated in a super-early PILGRED rush with a high level Raluca as my partner, and it... actually wasn't much fun at all, in retrospect. All we had to do was load up on spores and there was enough AP to go around to finish PILGRED between us, plus for me to transfer into the inactive commander. There was basically nothing the human team could have done to stop us, unless they'd happened to log in during the <10-minute rush window, noticed the two tracker dots in the engine room, and assumed the worst.

I guess it was a fun exercise in having an actual communicative mush partner, but it felt more like flipping the chessboard than actually winning the game. I probably won't be doing that again, except as a fallback to a more interesting scheme. Though granted, the characters we chose ended up being a critical factor in the victory as well (and I did have two spores pretty much the whole time), so the ease of Transfer was only part of it.
On december 13, 2014
Pave

The biggest problem with the transfer is the fact its downright "social-ruiner", especially at the end of the journey when you can't tell who was who and such.


On our current ship, we probably had a newbie who really wanted to learn and play this game. So I helped him around. Sure, it's not exactly certain whether he's pretending or not. But I still helped this player out of kindness.

Then around a day ago (as of this post) the mush-player(s) suddenly decided to go for a dismantling-rampage and other sabotaging, alongside trying to confuse rest of the players possibly with "Radio Pirate" too.

Of course since the ship was "full of" trigger-happy-players metagaming, a lot of human players got killed, because magically the transfer makes the previously controlled-character clean somehow...


My biggest problem here is going to be the fact that no one is going to who the "newbie" is going to be anymore, especially once the "post-game-credits" are being posted.
In fact, since the ship is currently going but soon ends due unnessarily being dragged longer, I personally have stopped talking at all. And after this session / ship, I don't even dare to try to private-message to this maybe-still-newbie-player, because I have no idea if this is still the same player to begin with.

I know "it's just part of the game", but when you're genuinely making people just not wanting to play the game anymore, you're not helping anyone for the most part...


End note: In my view, using Transfer is powergaming (or being a "munchkin" to pen & paper / tabletop-folks), and it should be removed until it's actually fixed.


If the person whom I actually tried to help around, especially when he became the unwilling-Commander, I truly apologize for being a "sore-loser" and walking-off the game, even if my last public-message was somewhat hinting...
In my defence, the setup already was so messed-up and downright almost fully against players. So once again after we got everything sorted out with lots effort put into it, I for one personally was really hoping the mush-players would had have more sportsmanship-sense ever since we got rid of the idling-tactics using players alongside the other griefers, again...

I apologize for such rant brough due the particular ability / mechanic; I just had to get it out of the system...I'll just stop wishing about good things while playing game to make everything easier give up upon...

- Transfer mechanic is really interesting. I don't want to lose it completely.

On december 13, 2014
Pave
Kyubey- Mushes already losing more than half of games (even when you count ships with tons of idles, who die themselves as mush victories). Just nerfing/removing one of most popular and strong skills will make humans win even more. Not good.

And once again, here is where the whole problem lies once again in this "game" (as I've ranted already on some other threads): The mentality of "have to win the game".

I may be a little wrong here, but as far I've understood this "game" called Mush is supposedly to more graphical / modern / straightforward & easily navigable-version of "MUSHes".
Oh sure, there also have been "dungeon-crawling"-MUDs around. But as far as I've understood the Mush of TwinMotion is supposed to be more roleplaying-focused, especially to consider not initially knowing who plays as who characters-wise.

Also just saying the "mush lose more than humans" is not simply enough: Where are all the details of "why" mush is losing more than humans?
Is it because the inactives / XP-farmers?
Is it because of heavily optimized metagaming (context-wise: Hunting)?
Is it just because things are made so that the "mush" is always in disadvantage because of some mechanics?

I for one don't know, but some do: I'd certainly would like to read more about these details if they'd be actually written somewhere. But far only things I've seen the text of "mush loses more" without details...

On december 13, 2014
[7950824]

Pave, I'm aware you're doing a lot more than saying 'I don't understand how to tell who a person is, ever, after transfer may have happened', but that's the point I'll address here:

Take a look at this endpage. In it I was initially Alpha Eleesha. I switched with Kuan in that game.

http://mush.twinoid.com/theEnd/6203

You know how to open up the 'history and glory' tab that looks a bit like a clipboard?

It doesn't say everything notable you do, to my observation, I have always seen both sides of a transfer listed. You can also see that Eleesha is not Impet, but Kuan is.

And that's how it works, it's that simple to follow, at least after the game is over.

If you choose to, you can even properly give likes by checking the endpage through your account page before you write your end comment and assign likes.

I have nothing else to say about your points because I think I understand how transfer works a lot better than you do, and where you see a complex and gamebreaking mess biased purely towards mush wins and absolute chaos, I see a challenging strategy that I'm happy to play with as mush or human. I don't know that you actually coming to really understand how transfer works and doesn't work would affect your feelings about it at all, but it is a bit.... shortsighted.... to declare something broken and game breaking before you actually understand how it works, what its limits are, how to notice when it happens, and wise human strategies for dealing with it once it appears to have occurred.
On december 13, 2014
[7950824]

As to 'Is Mush a Multi-User-Shared-Hallucination, next gen'.... No. In my opinion, and in the evidence I have seen.

I believe Mush is based on the game MAFIA, where you have a 'town' or collection of human players who do not know each others' identities, and among them a small collection of 'mafia', who do know who each other are and need to slowly eliminated (or rarely convert) the humans. Most different from Mafia, Mush does not have 1 player voted to die at the end of each day and the mafia free to kill one player of their choosing at night.

But I've played a lot of MUDs, and no.... Mush The Dawn is nothing like most MUDs or MUSHes. Roleplay is welcome here, encouraged.... but not required at all. Requirement to RP would be in the rules if that was a requirement.
On december 13, 2014
Kyubey

the whole problem lies once again in this "game": The mentality of "have to win the game"
is supposed to be more roleplaying-focused,
Let's see - we have two teams - humans and mushes. Humans are trying to survive themself, not to be infected and to give humanity itself a chance. Mushes are part of hivemind, they are given orders and are happy to die if needed to reach them. These things are in game lore and in rules (cannot play against your team, cannot surrender).
You can do any roleplay, while it is in those borders and not breaking any other rules ofc. But - if you are given role of survivor, who fights to the end (unless his morale is totally broken and he commits suicide) - you cannot roleplay somebody, for whom win the game is not the goal.
And as Impet states - transfer is just mush ability. And your character can probably know how transfer work, as mushes probably used that on Earth too, before you took off.

On december 21, 2014
Kyubey

A lot of suggestions happened about glory...but let me do another one And yes, I personally don't care about glory now at all, because it's so far away from really being useful (especially while playing mush). But if it will be, would be good!

Main ideas:
- Glory here represents two things - who hard player was trying and if he was successful. Both are rewarded.
- All human characters have quite same difficulty to get glory
- Mushes get glory if they win, stealing it from humans. More humans got, more mushes get from winning such humans. They don't need to be fast to get more glory, they don't need to kill or convert humans themselves to get it, if their other tactic is successful.
- Transfer does little effect on glory.

Ship glory:
Quite all human activities (like killing hunters, doing research and visiting planets) don't give any personal glory, but instead increase special pool - it represents, how much ship achieved overall.
When game ends it will be given in 2 forms (you can see both below):
1) Humans and mushes will be given % of the number, depending on which team and how has won
2) Humans will be given some extra glory for their ranks (see below)

Characters objectives:
All humans have their objectives, but they have few diffeneces.
- All glory for objectives is capped for everyone (for example on 30 glory)
- You will not be able to reach that cap on your own and fast (like now Roland can just kill hunters). You'll get some glory, but to get more you'll need ship to survive longer or others do job with you
- Objectives cannot be farmed infinitely
Roland gets +5 glory for each new type of ship he defeated. +5 for regular hunter, +5 for arack, +5 for trax, +5 for asteroid, +5 for D1000, +5 for transport.
Raluca gets +2 glory for each 20% PILGRED repairs. After PILGRED is online she gets +1 glory for each extra coffee taken from machine (until she gets 20 this way)
Hua gets +1 glory for each different zone on the planet she visited (+1 for Forest, +1 for Mountain) until she visit 30 different zones.

Ranks:
All jobs are important around the ship. When game ends, game calculates how much each player did. Best 3 of each are rewarded with extra glory. Different ranks give different number of glory, because some costs much more ap to get, and it will be quite impossiable for "best pilot" to get anything else. First place gives more then second and third. Some examples:
- Best pilot (3 people who killed most of hunters or maybe did more damage to hunters)
- Best tech (most of things repaired, but important and difficult to repair stuff like grav sim has more value then just doors)
- Best medic (most of health restored)
Mushes don't receive glory for getting that, but they get much more bonus glory for victories instead. If mush takes one of three prizes, it means, that humans just lost it.

Ending
Here are just examples to get the idea, numbers can be changed in any way and more conditions for each ending like number of other research, number of alien fruits ect can be added.

Arriving to Eden without mushes
Humans: 150% of ship glory
If alive: +25%
With RFS: +25%
Mushes: 0

Arriving to Eden with mushes
Humans: 50% of ship glory
If alive: +25%
With RFS: +25%
Mushes: 200%
Bonus for each extra mush: +25%

Return to Sol without mushes
Humans: 75% of ship glory
If alive: +15%
With RFS: +25%
Mushes, if RFS was done: 20%
Mushes, if RFS wasn't done: 40%

Return to Sol with mushes
Humans: 25% of ship glory
If alive: +5%
RFS changes nothing.
Mushes: 100%
Bonus for each extra mush: +15%

Ship destoyed
Humans: 25% of ship glory
Mushes who were killed earlier: 60% of ship glory
Mushes who survived until the end: 80% of ship glory
Mushes who got ticket into void: 100% of ship glory
RFS changes nothing.
On december 22, 2014
Aerial

On december 22, 2014
Flash

Suggestion:
(I don't remember if something like this has already been suggested)

Have an examine button available when selecting people in your room similar to when selecting equibment. Let it cost 1 AP per examination (passive action) and let it reveal any physical injuries (such as broken arms or missing tongues) that the examinated character has sustained. It should produce a public room log such as: "[name1] seems to be examining [name2] with great interest".

The examination could also give some vague feedback of the target's health such as:
16-8hp = "It's difficult to tell but [name] looks fairly healthy."
7-4hp = "[name] looks like they have seen better days."
3-1hp = "Maybe it's all the blood but it's obvious that [name] is in urgent need of help."
It is important here that a bronze/silver mode Mush can get away with a splashproof-less shower without getting chewed out more easily than they could have been with a medkit test.

Additionally there could be added a bonus to the Nurse skill which makes the examine action free (similar to Tracker's free searches).

The reason for this suggestion is that it seems strange that you cannot see fairly obvious injuries like missing limbs or burns covering the entire body.

What do you guys think? Unbalanced? Unnecessary? Nice?
On december 22, 2014
1412

That..
Actually seems like a useful and well-balanced thing to add. Huh.
