On march 23, 2015
Flash

A suggestion for more items:

Items that when carried protect either against injuries of a specific kind or from critical hits from certain weapons. Could come prebuilt or in blueprint format.

Examples:
Plastic Mouthguard - protects the wearer from biting their tongue during combat.
Antique World War Helmet - protects the user from blaster headshots. Also reduces damage of steel plates by 1 but each event might cause the helmet to break and require repairs.
Improvised Bomb Disposal Suit - protects the carrier from from self-caused damage when using any kind of explosive weapon and overall reduces damage taken from these weapons by 3. May break and require repairs on any damage taken.


More types of weapons and different ways to use them. Should come from blueprints as well as space capsules.

Examples:
Proximity Mine - has a medium chance to causes 3-5 damage to the next person that enters the room after activation. High chance to break doors and/or equibment in the room (making it look like the person sabotaged something). Consumed on detonation. Can be thrown like a grenade but will deal less damage.
Thermal Mine - has a high chance to start a fire when the next person enters the room after activation (makes it look like the triggering person used the Pyromaniac skill). Consumed on detonation. Can be thrown like a grenade but may cause severe burns to the user.
Smoke Grenade - when thrown in a room it lowers all attack chances by a small amount for two cycle. Gives cameras a 25% chance to miss covert actions and prevents Mycoalarms from functioning. Can be upgraded to a Smoke Mine using one piece of metal scrap and placed in a room for the same effect.

Just some random things I thought of.
On march 24, 2015
Kyubey

Well, I see current system of desplaying skills quite bad for such paranoia game.

- Add an option - "advanced human skills" - a player can always select all his human skills manually, even if his low level don't give him any choice.
- As human you can see only your skills
- As mush you can see skills of all mushes (both mush and human skill) - well, this is not necessary

What those will change:
- You can play casting with low lvl characters and some exp to spend. As silver you don't need to lvl up Chao to at least lvl 3 not to be given shooter+wrestler if game RNG chooses him for you.
- Mush can counter ap-counting without lvl 11 and eating spores. For example being Janice with IT and spending all ap in nexus, while really keeping some for spores+shower.
- Stealing mage book will be quite possiable for mush
- Can be useful for humans too - if mushes are uncertain if Hua, KT, Eleesha are Teches as well and if Jin Su is not only pilot (well, this one is easy to discover), but also a Leader, they will probably use less rampages, as it will be difficult to be sure, humans would not survive losing all important skills.
- Will allow using transfer to confuse, now it's too oblivious how it happened. Using transfer to idle to use 12ap on killing became too much the main way to use transfer
On march 24, 2015
ActualTrump

Items
---

Shock paddles: Wonderful and quite insane tool to give yourself (At a high risk of injurying yourself, you oaf.) or another crew member a jolt of energy by spending two AP to waste the time charging up said hand-held paddles and applying it the torso of your friend (Or enemy) Giving them or yourself five MP.

Side effects include numbness, 1-2 HP loss and only being able to use it on yourself or a crew member ONCE per day. After that, they gain a tempoary injury called (Shocked!), Lasting exactly until the same cycle the next day.
On april 1, 2015
The_Lioness

I haven't been playing very long but I'm fresh meat and think I have good perspective on the good and bad of the game.

I have learned a lot from more experienced players, yet think players should be grouped on ships based on number of games played. People who have played under 10 games could have a specialized explanatory game format with USEFUL tips and hints. It could go something like 0-10, 11-20, 25-50,50+ It's bad for newer players to get chewed out by less forgiving Mush veterans, yet the first few games are important for establishing future play - you want them to come back, right?

I also think there should be a system to ping people for inactivity. Not as a punishment, but to disperse the amount of regular inactives per ship. This would help with inactives who are people who play a few games and never play again, as they'd never get past the 10 game minimum to progress. The more you play, you get grouped with more experienced players and encounter fewer inactives.

This would need some kind of internal algorithm, but I think would be the single most effective way to enhance satisfaction with what is fundamentally a TEAM game.

I've seen moderators and other people say to "tough" it out, but people spend money on this game - they need to think like MARKETERS. On that note, bronze should include 2 abilities, silver 3, gold 4. Players should have fun but also be effective without spending money. Penalizing people with only one ability also penalizes the gold and silver players on the same ship who depend on them.
On april 1, 2015
1412

The thing about grouping inactive players with newbs is that the newbs join a game and are like, "Hrm, really? Doesn't seem like many people are talking... shame, this game seemed cool."
I do think a better tutorial is needed though.
On april 1, 2015
The_Lioness

Inactives wouldn't be grouped. The system would attempt to disperse accounts pinged for multiple cases of inactivity within a frame of time across many ships.

The second suggestion, grouping players by games played, is another way of dealing with inactives of another variety - new or inexperienced players.

Basically, two ways of dealing with inactives.

New players make not readily pick up on certain strategic actions (like dismantling a shower), but they should know basics for survival and mush hunt, how to win, what roles each character has.

On april 2, 2015
[8747164]

I kind of disagree with this idea... The best way to learn is (and will always be to my point of view) to learn by your self. Moreover, most players are actually very welcoming and help new players... And there's Mushpedia, which can help you to resolve many problems and is not hard to find on the forum. The current tutorial isn't that great, but that's the point : you must communicate with other players to understand what to do.
On april 2, 2015
The_Lioness

[cite The current tutorial isn't that great, but that's the point : you must communicate with other players to understand what to do][/cite]

Communicating with other players is for strategy. It should not be the main way of learning the game. Strong game design is the game explaining how to play itself (how to win, what characters do, their roles). Better player strategy comes from experience and other players.

On april 11, 2015
Kyubey

Killing Ian is not a problem at all. Even with fists it will take something like 30ap.

If you have blasters with shooter skill - it's just a shooter point per shoot. With Lizardo 99% to hit with 3-5 it's even easier. Even 2 grenades your ship has (one grenade, one BP) will do the work just for 6ap.

And if you made a natami, then it will be just 2 hits to kill any mush for sure - just 6 ap without shooter. If you have not researched it..well, you problem to face mushes hiding behind idle/mush Ian, as it's your problem to be converted, if you don'a research gas and serum.

The only situation when it can be a problem to kill mush-Ian - you have no solid/wrestler, he has armor/armor skill and all weapons are unreachable (for example mush-Ian put all those into refectory and guarding CC).

On april 15, 2015
Nihil

I once had an interesting idea where there was a third group that you could play as. It would be just like a normal game of Mush except instead of starting out with two Alpha Mush, you started with 1 Alpha Mush and 1 Alpha (lets call it Nush) who would need to hunt each other as well as destroying the ship. The Nush would be the same as the Mush except everybody they infected would also become Nush and they were required to destory the Mush before destorying the Ship. Also the Mush and Nush wouldn't be able to infect each other and even create a message saying they couldn't become infected since they were a M/Nush. This would create another layer of paranoia and intrigue where you would need to figure out who would be Human, Mush, and Nush. And develop a sense of Paranoia for the Alphas at the begining of the game.

An added bonus would be if the Nush were given new abilities exclusive to them that the Mush couldn't have. It would turn the game into a more cat-and-mouse style hunt.

When you invite people to a private chat, the person who does the first invite should be in control of the chat and be able to kick people from it.

I mainly want this because the chat interface can be finicky at times and I have invited people to the wrong chat and I have seen other people invite the wrong person. This would be a quick easy fix and not change much in the game at all.

TeufelsAdvokat

SDF sanctions should only be discussed in the mod inbox and kept private. There's no reason for players other than the mods or oneself to know about SDF points and sanctions. A casting director or whoever else would be permitted to receive this message are in the end just other players.

However, castings should and can easily sort out themselves: Basically by heavy stalking checking the player's profiles, distinctions or whatever you think will help.

On april 22, 2015
sperbi

It depends how carefully you are looking.
If someone has the patience to check many ships of the person, checking the amount of likes, whether someone is saying something negative or positive about the person in question in their end message, whether the person died often because of assassination/starvation, etc.
And even if that checking fails, castings can always kick the players out after they caused some trouble and will probably remember to not invite the person again.

On april 22, 2015
Chime

Yes it will, you just need to properly stalk them (oh lord)
Sure not every ill-doer has a Quarantined Death to offer in his record but you can read the end pages, see how many likes they got in comparison to the rest of the crew, what they left as last words and if some of the others felt the need to state in their last words what an idiot the person you stalk was. Etcetera, etcetera.


If you plaster everyone's faces with numbers equalling their SDF points that would just cause prejudice, especially since you can't know if they got their points for let's say forgetting to drop something during neutral play or because they didn't like someone's face and thus smashed it. Nobody likes to be reminded of their past mistakes everyday. And if we take the mush who's exposing himself and asks for a cure from the Q&A Question as example, he'll (probably) get reported, he may or may not get his share of points for that, I don't know how the clockwork works, but he will (hopefully) learn from it. Let's for the examples sake assume he gets x points and learns from it. If you put those x points on him like stigma, openly visible for others (or as I assume that's what you were trying to get at: "just" the other casting people). Before any casting will even have the chance to say "Sorry, we don't take people with x points" the player might think to himself "No casting will ever take me with x points" and not apply in the first place skipping out of the wonderful but unlikely chance that they say "No problem, welcome to our casting".

I could give you a few example Endpages from my own records, some where I cursed at others, some where others cursed at me, some where otherwise totally awesome people to play with flunked it and made some awful choices... but I guess everyone can find them in their own records somewhere.

On may 1, 2015
Flash

Just a few things I can think of that will help improve the Mush win rate more than the current 'injuries on wakeup' ever will. Read the wall at your own risk.

Suggestion A:
Change the stainproof apron to have a 66% chance of not making one dirty as opposed to complete protection from it (in most cases).

Bonus: give the apron a small chance (such as 5%) to break after saving someone from getting dirty and a high success rate to be repaired by non-techs (like 75%). Repairing it should make one dirty at the rate of any other repair action.

Reason A:
The act of getting dirty (and having a reason to enter the often only dorm with a shower) is too important to the balance of the game for there to be a guaranteed way of staying clean in the early game in my opinion. Additionally, certain characters that are expected to do research have very few chances to legitimately create spores when Mush if pitted against a knowledgable crew (i.e. not typical random ships). Having actual options to their strategies for these Mush characters might also help make them more interesting to play as.

Having a chance to get dirty from doing research also slows the advancement of it down a fair bit in addition to providing an option for Mush to help on the research without necessarily shooting themselves or their team members in the foot because they would get potential showers out of it.

The suggestion will also improve the value of certain skills like Finola's OCD.

Lastly it would also make picking torture targets as Chao a tiny bit more difficult which will go a long way towards a better Mush win rate.

-

Suggestion B:
Allow Mush the action to shower in the refectory sink even when there are showers standing but still only allowing one sink-shower total per day. This action should be expensive AP-wise (4 AP) and be classified as a secret action which means it'll be logged in the room if a camera or another character is present.

Reason B:
Entering the shower dorm is the leading cause of Mush mortality in my experience on random ships and the Mush hunt is sometimes built up entirely around it. having an alternative (even if expensive and inefficient) could open up more strategies for the Mush while still allowing the humans to counter it (camera, Chun watching the room, etc.). Massive Mushification can only get you so far.

A reason to discuss where to put one of Gioele's extra cameras which in turn might open up a room for the Mush to capitalize on untill research catches up.

-

Suggestion C:
A bit far fatched maybe but make the use of the final level 18 Mush skill create a synergistic effect on your other skills or extend their effects to your team.

For example: if a Mush picks Massive Mushification (the final skill) in addition to Shower Proof and then uses the Massive Mushification, all his team members that are currently alive will now also have the effect of his Shower Proof skill. Any new additions to the team will not be affected.

Reason C:
While the level 18 Mush skill has its uses it always felt a bit underwhelming to me especially because of its spore cost. Allowing the skill to help your team which is often consisting of new or inexperienced bronze/silver players (on random ships) could go a long way. Has a big risk of being overpowered though.

Taking shower damage as Mush is really hurting bronze players and this could be one way of helping alleviate that.

-

Suggestion D:
A straight up Pheromodem nerf.
Require at least two dead Mush bodies before it becomes available.

Reason D:
Pheromodem is the end-all be-all of anti Mush research and completely shuts down a main aspect of the game - covert convertions. Requiring more than one dead Mush before being able to work on it could help the Mush teams where one makes a mistake that gets them easily killed, allowing the surviving one the option to still potentially convert someone covertly.

Has the bonus of being a simple yet far reaching change.

-

Suggestion E:
Remove the 100% foolproof way of telling if there are currently still live Mush players on your ship through the inability to print Eleesha's List.

Let the List be printable even if all Mush are dead and guarantee it to contain one of the (dead) Alpha Mush's names.

Reason E:
This gives beta Mush a chance to go on for a little longer or at least untill everyone else have been tested human. It also adds a bit more of the fun paranoia that keeps players on their toes as there could always another beta Mush.

Also a simple change with far reaching effects.

-

I have many, many more suggestions but the wall is already long enough and for something to actually come from it is about as likely as glory whores playing something other than Roland

On may 2, 2015
Chime

Did you fail to often as mush or where is that coming from? They are all ridiculous. You might aswell suggest to start with 3 mush, 1 extinguisher and 5 fires.
On may 2, 2015
Kyubey

Well, I can agree, that mush can have some help...but really not stuff like that. To deal with most of problems you already have tools.

Suggestion A & Suggestion B
The act of getting dirty (and having a reason to enter the often only dorm with a shower) is too important to the balance of the game for there to be a guaranteed way of staying clean in the early game in my opinion
Use Slimetrap. Or even just say, that somebody used Slimetrap on you.
Or make spores only after you got dirty already - help humans to load fuel, take part in expoes. Even somebody like Frieda or Finola can use that.
Also you can try Doorman skill. Just break a door just after cycle change, and humans will not get if it's random or not. If the door is important (like CC-refectory), you can try and fix it with any character and get dirty. Same works of Green Jelly, if there is nobody else in the room.

Suggestion C
MM is strong enough already. If you have MM, you can also have extra spore+free spores stuff, so the cost of 2 spores is not critical for the benefit it gives. Also with new injury and not-full-hp-at-start stuff mushes can just take damage from showers in most of situations.

Suggestion D & Suggestion E
Both list and modem can be destoyed. Dismantle Tabulatrix or Disk, kill or convert Tracker - if you think some human tool is too powerful against you - just focus on disabling it first.
On may 2, 2015
Flash
ChimeDid you fail to often as mush or where is that coming from? They are all ridiculous. You might aswell suggest to start with 3 mush, 1 extinguisher and 5 fires.

What makes them seem ridiculous to you? How would you change them?


Kyubey[snip]

Thank you but I'm not looking for advice. I have no problems winning as Mush. These are just random suggestions intended to help those who drag the Mush winrate down.

Regarding Suggestion C, yeah it's definitely an over the top suggestion but I still thought it seemed interesting. More options is good and some sort of synergy between skills could make less used ones more so and this is a thread for suggestions is it not?

As for Suggestion D & E, you will not always be in a position to prevent them and doing so will most likely give away your identity anyways. Not having a 'mush free check' is just healthy for the game overall in my opinion.
On may 3, 2015
Tpyo
FlashHave the humans get dirty more often

How about a variant of slime trap that acts like trapper so any action done in a room will make that person dirty after a few cycles. One of the drawbacks to slime trap is that an experienced player can explain their way out of the situation and you can only get slime someone in areas you can also spike someone so it can quickly be traced back to the mush. Since there are a lot of skills already, it could just be another part of slimetrap - kinda like how reinforce and dismantle are part of the same skill.
On may 4, 2015
Flash
TpyoHow about a variant of slime trap that acts like trapper so any action done in a room will make that person dirty after a few cycles. One of the drawbacks to slime trap is that an experienced player can explain their way out of the situation and you can only get slime someone in areas you can also spike someone so it can quickly be traced back to the mush. Since there are a lot of skills already, it could just be another part of slimetrap - kinda like how reinforce and dismantle are part of the same skill.

Sounds like a nice solution but how would it work in camera/mycoalarm protected rooms? What would the privacy level of the action be? If it were to have the same privacy levels as the Trapper skill then maybe it could trigger on the next person entering the room as opposed to the next person taking an action in the room? It still has the problem of requiring a skill slot and that's no good for bronze or silver Mush.
On may 7, 2015
Tpyo
FlashSounds like a nice solution but how would it work in camera/mycoalarm protected rooms? What would the privacy level of the action be? If it were to have the same privacy levels as the Trapper skill then maybe it could trigger on the next person entering the room as opposed to the next person taking an action in the room? It still has the problem of requiring a skill slot and that's no good for bronze or silver Mush.

A camera would show it, if it didn't then it would be nearly as obscene as green jelly was - the skill is already shown by a camera anyway. Mycoalarms probably shouldn't show it because you normally pick the skill when there are active researchers and a low chance of a converting many people. I suppose if it's just like trapper then people in the room could reveal it, but if it's combined with the current effect you could just slimetrap them since there wouldn't be camera.

Slimetrap only costs 1 AP, outside of being easily traced back - it's a half decent skill already. If it had a trap function akin to trapper it might even be too good since there isn't much of an investment outside of the skill slot. You could slimetrap the patrol ships and make everyone suspicious of the pilots, slime trap rear corridor so someone that picks up the fire extinguisher gets dirty,. Your goal is just to get the crew to trust each other less because it's too risky / ap intensive to convert someone - in that scenario it's the perfect skill for a bronze player who can only win by getting the crew to kill themselves.

On may 12, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Well, for one thing, hunters are the reason why Neron decides to wake up the crew from cryo (at least one of the reasons). From a game play point of view, it does add something, since it provides things to do from the start : killing the hunters from turrets or patrol ships (or moving the ship if the situation is getting really dangerous), collecting scrap...

The thing is, also, that the game is based on the French server, on which there are more players and ships fill faster. Starting hunters can do some damage, but it usually takes less time for pilots to wake up and deal with them.

I know that on the one hand, it is a little unfair because the English server is different and yet the game hasn't been adapted to those differences. On the other hand, since it takes so much time for some EN ships to fill, and also since neutral play is more encouraged on this server, hunters can be considered as a good way to spend your time and AP instead of just staying there doing nothing. There are lots of things that necessitate all players to be awake (mush hunting being the main one, of course). So instead of waiting for hours, you can deal with hunters, and now also with injuries. 4 hunters aren't that difficult to kill from turrets, and sepsis isn't a big deal either.
On may 12, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?
LokettaSuggested and refused under different circumstances.
Before injuries at the beginning some players were left with spare AP before selecting skills or seeing who was going to be active. There is now a lot less early AP for dealing with this because of the healing, injuries and sepsis incidents AND from what I am witnessing in games ships are getting slower to fill ( I imagine more to do with castings than a lack of players )

That's a bit contradictory, if you think about it. Ships were already a little slow to fill on this server, so it gave time to deal with hunters. Now you say that they're slower, which gives additional time to also deal with injuries (having Finola back is also an advantage, since it's easier to heal injuries with a medic ; and the fail rate isn't that high, so sepsis is rarely a huge problem).

And for the ships that fill faster, well, then hunters shouldn't be a problem since pilots wake up faster.

On may 13, 2015
sperbi

Not always though and it is kind of strange that whole mechanism, I admit that I don't like the current big and unpredictable role of the hunters in the game. After next moving...still 8 hunters...after third moving finally only 4 hunters. On may 13, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Oh, would be nice if it were like that. But we all experienced that moving is often triggering new waves. It is like that. That is how the game is designed, precisely to help ships which have trouble with hunters : moving reduces the number of hunters and makes it easier to get rid of them.

I am talking about the case when you already have hunters. Moving the ship only triggers new waves when you have no hunters at all before moving.

If you have hunters, move the ship, and get another wave after moving, then it's only because of bad luck. The escape mechanism (and Trail Minimizer, which makes the mechanism more efficient) work perfectly.
On may 13, 2015
sperbi
PeanutzIf you have hunters, move the ship, and get another wave after moving, then it's only because of bad luck. The escape mechanism (and Trail Minimizer, which makes the mechanism more efficient) work perfectly.

Why do I have always that bad luck I am asking myself then...
It is not the first ship where I am seeing something like that.
But well, I can't give any proof of course.
So I just really hope you are right ^^
On may 13, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

There's a difference between "it's not the first ship where I'm seeing something like that" and "I always have that bad luck". It's a bit like saying "it always rain when I don't take my umbrella", just because you notice it more when it happens, but when it rains and you do have your umbrella, you don't notice it.

Of course it happens. You have too many hunters, you move, and after moving, you have as many hunters or more. Some ships are even very unlucky and it often happens to them. But in that case there is no link between moving the ship and getting another wave. I have no proof either, except that I've been paying attention to it since I've been playing and I've seen the escape mechanism and Trail Minimizer work like a charm, much more often than I've seen additional waves. I have also been reading both forums (English and French, including beta forums whose only purpose is to report bugs) and if there really was a bug with the escape mechanism, it would have been reported.

Yes, I know, it sometimes comes up in the forums. But other wrong theories also come up regularly, things like "Gioele is never Mush", "I am always Mush when I play Paola", "The game is designed to prevent us from always choosing our favourite character", "Plasma Shield repairs the hull" or "Mycoalarms extract spores". Those are just examples, and the people who report them are ready to swear that it's true because they see it happen all the time. But it's not true.

On the other hand, the fact that moving when there are no hunters triggers new waves has been proven. But that is another problem. As for the problem we are talking about, if you have too many hunters, move the ship. If you aren't lucky and you get more hunters, then move again. The number will be reduced eventually.

On may 13, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?
FlashNo matter the consensus on the early game design nothing's going to change unless you campaign for it on the french forum

Actually, the suggestions here are about the same as on the French forum. So most of the time, we already know what the answer is going to be. As for "campaigning", it doesn't really work, especially if it's a petition or something like that. The devs rarely read the forums and rely on old beta forums or mods' forum to get a summary.


About the hunter waves, I was under the impression that any hunters lost by moving the ship would just increase the size of the next waves but no one's really got any real proof so it's difficult to argue about. The next waves do increase, but that would be the case whether you move the ship or not. Hunters, like fires, injuries and breakage, increase with time, and also increase according to the crew's activity and to what happened on the previous cycles (or days). Basically, the way it works is :
- You usually get one wave per day (sometimes two, but much less frequently).
- Each wave is bigger than the previous one, and the longer the ship lasts, the bigger the waves get. Moving the ship has no influence on that.
- If you get no hunters at all for one day or more, you're going to get a much bigger wave when the hunters finally spawn (for example, no hunters on D5 means that you're going to get roughly the number of hunters you should have had on D5 + the D6 hunters).
- If you move the ship after the hunters spawn, they're reduced by half. But the RNG bases its next decisions on the initial wave. So if you get 20 hunters, move to get 10 (or 5 with TM), the next day, you should get more than 20, because of the increase with time.


sperbiI could have sworn that I noticed moving with no hunters didn't always trigger a new hunter wave. That's why I thought there is just always a chance that a new hunter wave is triggered when moving, no matter how many hunters are there... But well, I should watch and collect screenshots and come back when I have watched enough.

Having no hunters after moving happens very rarely. I've seen it happen twice in the last two years (including one year on two different servers). 99% of the time, if you have no hunters and move, it triggers a wave (that can be accompanied by the normal, daily wave).

My theory is that when you move the ship, the RNG considers that you are moving away from hunters (because it thinks that moving = escaping). So it creates an imaginary wave of hunters, that you don't see, and half of them catch up with you when the ship stops. For example : you move the ship mid-C1, the RNG imagines a 20-hunter wave that supposedly dates from C1, and on C2, when the ship stops, you get 10 hunters (or 5 with TM).

The explanation is a theory. But saying that moving with no hunters triggers a wave is a fact, and there are many proofs :
- Any ship that often moves to do daily expeditions can notice it : they always have hunters, because they move all the time.
- Those waves are much smaller than the waves a ship would get if it didn't move so often. My current ship is on D10 and we only have mini waves of less than 10 hunters.
- A solid proof : if you have no hunters and move on C1, you can get hunters on C2. That is theoretically impossible, because C2 and C3 are hunter free. You never, ever get hunters on those cycles. Except if you move the ship on C1 or C2.
- Another proof (which also proves my theory to explain why it works like that) : for those waves (the waves triggered by moving), Strateguru triggers at the end of cycle cycle (just like when you are escaping hunters). For a normal, random wave, it triggers at the beginning of the new cycle.
On may 13, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Sorry, double message, but the first one was already too long.

The conclusion of this is that in fact, if you want to get smaller waves of hunters, you have to move more often in order to trigger additional waves. This sounds paradoxical, but in fact it's logical.

- If you don't move, let's say that you get 10 hunters one day, 12 the day after, 15 the next day, etc. If by any chance you get no hunters at all for a day or two, then you get a monstrous wave when they finally appear.

- If you move, you create additional waves that wouldn't have existed if you hadn't moved. The RNG imagines an invisible wave of 10 hunters (and reduces it the next cycle, since it considers that you're escaping). Which means that it will take those 10 hunters into account when deciding on the size of the normal daily wave. And that wave will be smaller than it should have been, since the RNG considers that you have already had 10 hunters.

On june 26, 2015
Kyubey

Some skills give more extra ap, some less, it mostly depends on other effects.
Tech and Phys give just 1-2ap per day most of the time (unless you dismantle something every day), but their bonuses to repairs, projects, PILGRED make them good anyway.
Chef, Designer or IT give 4ap per day, but their other bonuses are situatinal or small.
Logistics gives 8ap per bay, but nothing else.

Nurse and Shooter looks like exceptions here, as they provide just 2ap per day (mostly, as self-surgeries are rare, as well as shooting Ian), and they don't have other very cool bonuses as Tech for example.

Well, in my opinion, it's because those skills are great for emergencies. Those two skills are like Ceasefire action with Diplomat. Use these extra actions in the right moment, and you can change everything, but use them for maintenance like one extra 3hp heala after expo or 2 shoots with turret and difference will be small.

On august 8, 2015
Dzanek

I don't know if somebody has found the idea, but I looked at some skins of characters and some people showed each crewmemember how they look when they're tied up.

So I think there should be introduced the option to tie somebody up. This action should be made on inactive people so if they wake up, they should burn some AP to release.

Action: Tie up
Cost: 2 AP
The target must be inactive. To make playing Mush fun, they may tie up active people as well...
Required: Rope.
This action will consume the Rope. If person gets released or sold, the Rope will be dropped. But the amount of Ropes is limited to 2, maybe it should be enough. Or maybe do something useful with Duct Tape...
Target gets status Tied up. The target might be forced to drop all inventory...

Tied up: all actions cost 1 AP more, all movements cost 1 MP more. Unable to attack. Some more actions the person is forbidden to do... New action: Release

Action: Release
Cost: 1 AP
Chance: 12%, Knife doubles the chance, Solid doubles the chance.
Target: self
When succeed: removes status Tied up. Rope is knocked out in shelving-unit. Might hurt person even if fails.

What's the purpose?

I think most people will agree that just few inactive people enough to make a good rampage using transfer. When somebody is held as inactive to get sold, it depends on Mush if they have caprice to rampage or not, how the future of the ship is. This idea will just restrict the effectivity of rampage (especially on ships with inactive Chao/Derek) which just annoys human team. Of course it won't decrease the value of transfer if the Mush doesn't use it to rampage (for example to bypass the list of suspects to confirmed human).

The most annoying Mush if the one who does nothing the whole voyage. You suspect active people of possibilities to extract spores and spike someone, pointing at some of them and they do the same to you. You play a few days and you haven't found the Mush in active people because they cover very well. Suddenly, somebody inactive kills all Technicians and hijacks a Pasiphae. Where's the fun of Mush hunt when inactive person did unbearable thing which could do as Mush, but crew focused on the suspects whose list was being decreased. I've seen some high level people who instead of showing their skills of covering as Mush, they just go lurking and wait for the best moment when they can go rampage. If the idea was introduced, the Mush would be forced to be active to survive, and active Mush is what the game expects.
On august 8, 2015
[8747164]

I thought you could already tied people up with some duct tape ?

On august 16, 2015
[8885316]

This thread is long and it's probably been suggested many times, but would allowing alien traders to exchange mage books for inactive characters help the AFK problems most ships see? Like how you can trade Raluca for PILGRED, they would offer books that have a selection of that players skills.

You would still have to decide who to trust them with, and it would add additional burden on the crew to handle more jobs-but it would mean at least some essential skills-like pilot, technician, or shrink-would not go uncovered.

Also, lets bronze+silver players help the ship a bit more by taking up the slack with their reduced number of chosen skills, tho that may interfere with the business model.

A new pill: thereallife.

It cures any illness and disorders & all of them, if there's more than one.
Also, randomly, it gives:
-3 to +3 action points.
-3 to +3 morale points.
-4 to +4 movement points.
+3 Satisfaction points.

It can be only obtained trought random chance from Narcotic Distiller, while having very low chance to make one. (Yes, no random on beginning of ship).

On september 16, 2015
BadBlanket

I have a suggestion to help balance out Derek whose only real purpose is an extinguisher or transfer bait.

Motivator should be changed. Instead of giving MP after use, it should allow him to transfer his own AP to someone else at a penalty of 1MP per use (converting AP when no AP just like in movement). Before you say this is overpowered, Paola can give 1 whole AP every cycle without losing anything. This would be a lesser form of Logistics only it's an action that can be used as many times as Derek wants if he has the AP to do so.

Now you're asking, how is this useful if it's just a watered down logistics that renders Derek an AP injector? It'd be designed for use in emergencies. Obviously if Derek were to give 1 AP to someone every cycle (costing him his cycle AP and cycle MP) would render him completely immobile and less useful so it would be an inefficient use of AP in the long run. However, there are times where something needs to be done before cycle end where only a specific character can accomplish it. Derek can swoop in and inject some AP into said character before cycle end and the problem is then solved.

For example: someone has 0 morale and misjudges AP use when heading to DTT but suddenly doesn't have the AP to do so and that's his only way to get morale. Derek can save them. Maybe the ship has barely any hull and a few hunters outside but the only active pilot is lacking the AP to fly out for an efficient run, Derek comes and fuels them. Etc.
On september 17, 2015
[8281990]

And it would suit the skill name better. I like it.

Especially since the main concern I'd have (how does this affect Mush play?) is honestly contrary to Mush Derek's strength. Sure, he could contribute AP to a PILGRED rush, but at the cost of his own ability to act. AP in a mush Derek's hands is a scary thing, and the ability to give it up (with a tax to boot) would be an interesting strategic choice. Nice for defanging yourself as human Derek by distributing any excess AP before you log out for a while, too. And you still have to pick your recipients wisely.
On september 21, 2015
[8794477]

Idea: Mush report screening board

Description:
I propose a 'second tier' (or lack of a better term) of SDF volunteers who's only purpose is to +1 reports that involve serious rules violations. The point of which would be to help get actual serious matters to the judges' attention quicker.

Implementation:
This would be an 'up-vote only' type of thing. Every report should get its due analysis, so no down-voting since the 'tier 2' people would not be as skilled/trained in detecting more subtle violations. This would also prevent spiking reports - the abuse of which would have a chilling effect on player trust of impartiality of the SDF process. Allowing up-votes would allow for abuse too, but the effect wouldn't be that terrible. Requiring a several votes for a report to be flagged as a priority would make it harder to abuse in this way as well.

It would work like this:
If a report gets 3 (or whatever number) upvotes of 'I validated that I saw a serious rules violation' it would up the report's place in the judge's queue for review, while still not tanking reports where the violation is more subtle. Also, it would not be a 'must go through tier 2 first' thing to prevent any artificial barriers to a report getting to the judges if the tier 2 folks are asleep at the wheel. It would only serve to help judges triage reports to give priority to the ones most likely to need it.

A similar system for reviews of SDF points disputes could be done along the lines of 'I validated this player's dispute. The points were probably awarded in error. Please review.' so that judges could prioritize their time towards the most likely disputes. Again no down-votes so that every challenge receives review in its due consideration eventually.

What do ya'll think?

John Kowalsky (A normal citizen of Sol system)

1. Observant (You've been always curious... as kid, as worker, as normal guy. You wanted to know everything, even if newest gained knowledge was less useful than a destroyed empty box)
2. Worker (You just like to work... and that's how you spend most of your time and life...)
Bonus to all researches and projects by +1%, also you don't lose your progress by doing so.
[If John has 7-10% of progress of research/project, he always maintain it, his progress don't have to be reset by anyone else]
3. Detached Crewmember (You never wanted to have anything to do with them, you just wanted to do your job...)
4. Survivalist (Others? Don't know, don't care. I am the only one who wants to matter.)
5. Caffeine Junkie (Friends? Free time? Who needs that, if you have coffee and your work.)
6. Power of Body (Deep down in your heart, you always have been dreaming of having your own 5minutes on global scene... or at least more power to work!)
Twice times per ship, you can convert your MP into AP, which includes AP into MP. Ratio 1:1.

NGJonAlternatively a trade where you can trade out highly inactives and keep a signal open where in that period someone else can choose that character and join the ship in their place

Actually, that idea might be expanded into:

If there's traded offer for exchanging crewmember for crewmember, random people should receive a possibility to replace exactly the same character with same character but:
- Player that can replace grand inactive player, have a green-colored window around character portrait (that indicates "trade" onto ship)
- All characters to have basic uniform color-changed, to make it clear for other, he's from trade (for example: Ian basic outfit being green instead of yellow)
- Traded characters get replaced character morale/health/glory cut in half
- Replacing characters have to be player in gold mode or silver mode, their skill selection is cut in half. (1 and 2), on top of that, gold days are not to be lost
- Custom outfits from vending machine doesn't not work if you're a character from trade
- If traded character turns inactive, it either dies from fatal depression or cannot be traded again for another player
- Profile players get "Alien Slave xO" counter on their profile where O stands for number of times they were replacing inactive player.

On january 6, 2016
Aceb
NGJonI was actually thinking of the penalties it might impose to the mush team if one person gets and inactive till he goes grand inactive and then a mush team member with half abilities, also it will slightly devalue the gold /silver status of extra skills, It might discourage people from going gold/silver (or it might not, i personally like the idea of helping out a struggling ship)

Look at it from another side. Inactive gots traded and active guy gets on. Mush/humans doesn't not lose a member and actually GAIN from this instead of LOSE. This is not existing option, so it's bad to use it in a way of "penalty" becuase it's 100% gain.

While I agree silver players might get offended by that, because they're reduced back to one skillslost for duration of "trade-ship", but in first place, they're just replacement. Personally, I would hate to see that grand inactive 1lvl Eleesha get replaced with Gold Eleesha that take 4 skills and save the day. That's way too much advantage from such trade in my opinion and well, the person gets off from slave(?) tradeship, not from lil'comfortable cryo.

Also Gold players don't lose their gold days (but their XP gain is cut in half!) and can help a ship with 2 skills as somekind-silver player and keep their gold days for longer.

Also, gold players are highly unlikely going to get inactive, so I guess gold player getting into shoes of silver one as a mush, is pretty fair.

So I think mush players should get XP for infecting and converting humans. That way the riskier (and much more interesting) mush strategy will also reap a bigger reward.

[8281990]

As a potential tech, Hua is too valuable to replace with a non-tech. Andie is fine. I've had crews pull together anti-mush research in good time without skilled researchers at all this season, and when you do have a Polyvalent Andie, that's a cheaper Diplomat and higher chance at Eden. (And when I'm Finola, I'm silver and don't double up research skills anyway, so it's basically the same)

But then again, I don't mind slightly slower research. It gives Mush breathing room and gives humans something to investigate... instead of those Mush playing human/inactive and then rampaging because all the important research was done before they even logged in post-selection. Much more interesting and when the humans are good, less destructive to the crew.

Would love to see Chun get access to Medic, though. Even as a level 6 skill.

On february 20, 2016
Aceb

6 skill for Derek: Jailor.

New Action: JAIL

- Cost 10 PA
- Selected crewmate is jailed in current room for 4 cycles, can't attack and can't be attacked directly
- All actions of this crewmate are visible for everyone to view
- Jailor automaticaly become guard of the room and can't move out of the room and neither can target
- Efficiency of jailed crewmate is always low and repair chance is always cut in half
(instead of for example: 6-9% it's 6%, 3-6% it's 3%, and so on)
- Any holding items that are not personal are dropped by Jailor and jailed crewmate
- Jailed crewmate has a chance to get visible panic attack with 10% when jailed and +10% for every next cycle (always 1% chance of revealing in logs that target is a mush instead of panic attack [same as shrink])
- Any aggressive action that is non-combat, cost 2 more PA for jailed mush
- Jailor and jailed person can't pick up any items that aren't personal
- Reveals X last actions of target [Where X stands for (HP + Morale)/4 of Jailor]

New Action: Execute (if jailed) [aggressive action]

- For 2 PA, this crewmember will be immediatly put down without any possibility to reserve this action
- It's affected by Chao Crazy eyes or Ian Pacifist
- If jailor is human and executed crewmember was also human, jailor lose 6 morale/glory and gets weapon phobia, hand-to-hand combats are -20% likely to succes
- If jailor is human and executed crewmember is mush, jailor gains 1 morale and 6 glory
- It happens only on cycle change, cannot be canceled and is announced in logs
- Can make you dirty

New Action: Free (if jailed)

- For 2 PA, you set free this crewmember and lose your guard trait
- It happens only on cycle change
- Can make your target dirty (while in jail also)
- Happens automatically if jailor dies



Just wild idea I got before going to sleep. If not a little cons of this suggestion, it would suit more Chao, but I wanted to make something for Derek

Aceb
Vereni see no point to waste 10! yes 10!! AP just to restrain someone when you can kill him with only 5 (as Derek )

If You're lucky with your punches, never miss and always deal top damage, it's true. BUT.
Killing is not always a good option. And not everyone are that lucky with RNG.
if target is mush ... what will you do in the next 4 cycles? wait for a random event to confirm he's mush ?
There's actually a plenty of things. You want to give your team a time to research RFS or it's night time and You don't wanna wake up dead for several reasons. There's a few suspects and unnecessary killing might bring You all down. You can protect with risk a human. Etc.
with this you just tell the target you think he's mush, something like "hey guy, i know your mush, but i let you 4 cycles to restore AP and start your rampage, have fun " (btw mush confessing to shrink is way lower then 1%, considering the very high number of ships and very low number of eleesha confessing )
1% was example, I don't know myself how much the chances are but I wanted to make it "similar".
Also I don't want the jailor skill to be abused (it has also little detective "torturer" in it). Yes, that's true that your target can regain a few PA but if your crew is prepared, it doesn't give mush that much.
if target is human... what will you do? hope for a random panic that will prove him human (don't we have enough tests with foodthat you want 1 more way to proove human ?

New Early level Mush ability:
"Fungify Metabolism"

Effect:
Once per day for 1 AP you can stop someone eating for the entirety of that day.

Uses: You could cause people to starve by using it on them every day, or make people blunder stuff like the food test and be executed. You could also claim you were afflicted with this should some unfairly playing crew think to run the food test on you!

Privacy Level: Private or Mush.

What do you guys think?

On april 22, 2016
res7less

I have been made aware, that this thread exists, so I will post the things I said in a separate thread here.

While I do appreciate the change from Finola and Chao to Derek and Andie and back again, it slowly starts feeling like recycling and it's time to have a new pair of characters to enter the void. While I am fully aware that the suggestion will very likely be ignored, I still would like to put my thoughts to letters so they can stop keeping my head busy. Who knows, maybe some of the things could come to fruition one day.

Before I begin, I would like to add that I haven't thought of how two more characters would end up on the ship since in games it's always "form follows function" and here I would like to suggest functions.

Character 1: Professor Stein (or any other name - doesn't really matter)

I feel like technology like drones are not being useful enough even if there is an active Terrence aboard and tons of scrap. Terrence usually ends up being a full time technician or pilot, while all those robot stuff is being neglected. I would like to see a character, who can actually be very useful not as a technician only, so here's the Terrence replacement's skillset:

Level 1: Gadget Expert (or Gadgeteer)

Passive: Bonus on NERON projects (same as robotics expert)
Passive: Can create gadgets

Active: For 2 AP, 2 Plastic Scraps and 1 Scrap Metal the Gadgeteer can create a gadget (item), that can be attached to a character.

Attaching it costs another 1 AP, but can be done by anyone on anyone. Attaching is permanent and the character, the gadget is attached to, receives a status icon, that he is wearing a gadget, that is visible for everyone. No more than 1 gadget can be attached to a character.

Gadget types:

  • Rocket Boots: Wearer receives 1 MP more from AP to MP conversion. Stacks with similar effects like scooter, sprinter etc.
  • Reinforced Knuckles: Melee attacks deal 1 additional point of damage. Adds 1 point of combat strength during expeditions. Stacks with similar effects.
  • Occular Enhancers: Adds 10% chance of hitting shots. Works with blaster (and other ranged weapons), turrets, patrol ships. Stacks with other similar effects.
  • Nano Healing Bot: Wearer recovers 1 additional HP per day.
  • Maintenance Helper: Adds 10% to the success rate of repairing equipment. Stacks with other similar effects.

This skill makes sure that Plastic Scaps finally get some use as well. And it can considerably enhance the crew in time to be a lot more effective. While one or two gadgets might not make much difference, a fully gadgeted crew can be quite effective overall. The gadgets can be attached to character depending on their roles, helping the ship to adapt to different situations.

Level 2: Designer

This makes sure he can participate in projects, while being able to reserve some AP for his gadgets.

Level 3: Technician

This is a must for a Terrence replacement.

Level 4: Tinkerer

Passive: Dismanle, Reinforce and Strengthen actions cost 1 AP less.
Passive: Strengthen has a 20% increased success rate. (resulting in 95% success with wrench and oscilloscope)
Passive: +2-3% efficiency on fixing PILGRED (which is half of Physicist)
Passive: Dismantling certain items grants 1 additional Plastic Scrap.

Level 5: Pilot

This is to make sure he can also collect scraps. Being powerful in other areas he should not have the shooter skill.

Level 6: Eidetic Memory

Active: For 4 AP and once per game he can create a Blueprint of his choice, that he perfectly remembers from his studies.

Not sure, which blueprints exactly should be available as having 2 sofas each game sounds a bit too powerful, but a must would be an extinguisher blueprint to counter the set-on-fire-and-escape-on-Pasiphae-Mush-play. Probably just all non-weapon blueprints (as human) - this way there would be no second tube, while for Mush all blueprints should be available. This skill could fill a hole if the ship is missing important blueprints like Babel Module or Oscilloscope.
On april 22, 2016
res7less

Character 2: Sherman Lockwood (Sher Lock - get it?)

Following his name, this should be a replacement for Eleesha. I kind of imagine this guy be a true detective, who loves to solve cases but with a spleen that he sees them as fun, ignoring all seriousness. But then, as soon as stuff gets real, he is completely in over his head. He is basically the contrary of Derek: while Derek is unable to find the bad guys, but once they're found he can easily kill them, Sherman can find the evildoers but is completely unable to do anything against them. So, his skillset:

Level 1: Analytical Coward

While Eleesha is observant, being able to tell things after they happened, Sherman is able to predict things before they happen by analyzing the situation.

Passive: When using the Search action Sherman marks a room. All secret and covert actions in this room will become public for Sherman (no one besides him sees the entries). Only one room can be marked at the same time and using Search in another room will move the mark to the current room.
Passive: When a secret or covert action happens in such a room, Sherman will receive the "Panicking" status (visible to everyone when clicking on Sherman). The status will stay until Sherman has searched another room. "Panicking" will cause everything he writes in the public chat to appear in capital letters and end with "!!".

While this skill might not be able to catch a Mush every time, it will sure force the Mush to avoid rooms Sherman walked through, since they don't know which one of them is marked. The Mush also won't know immediately if they have been revealed or not. Furthermore it gives the game a fun-factor since the panic can also trigger from simple things as eating, possibly raising an unnecessary alarm by a human until Sherman verified which action it was. It kind of becomes a "The Boy Who Cried Wolf" child story scenario. The Mush could coordinate to try and find the room by 1 Mush staying near Sherman to watch if his status appear and the other hiding some object with the excuse of just wanting to make a dangerous object unavailable for Mush. There might come different things to experiment with this skill.

Level 2: Tracker

A must-have as Eleesha's replacement - Sherman should also be able to print THE List.

Level 3: Storyteller

Passive: Able to use "Brag" action once per day. After the first dead Mush "Brag" turns into "Tell story".

  • Active (before 1 dead Mush):
    For 2 AP Sherman tells everyone in the room about how awesome it will be to find out the Mush and about his genius plans to make it happen and how he will totally outwit them. No one can take Sherman seriously. As the humans (except himself) think "Oh shit, we're screwed having this guy as our detective", they lose 2 morale, while the Mush's present in the room will have their next action cost 2 AP more.
  • Active (after 1 dead Mush):
    For 2 AP Sherman tells everyone in the room about how he alone was able to get a Mush killed, which will raise the Morale of every human (including Sherman) by 2.

As the Mush tend to do things in one go, this will make sure to harm their burst exploits, no matter what their plans are. It will certainly harm earlygame plays but in the long run, the humans would lose too much morale if Sherman does it every day. But this skill before dead Mush might give the humans just enough time to finish important researches while after 1 dead Mush it can become a viable source of morale to make up for the early uses.

Level 4: Nurse

Being a worrywart Sherman of course knows how to treat wounds.

Level 5: Firefighter

Sherman is also afraid to burn alive, so he knows how to extinguish fires.

Level 6: Wanton Imagination

Active: For 6 AP Sherman will dive deep into his imagination and roleplay a Mush for 3 cycles (visible in public chat). He can see and communicate in the Mush chat (including recent spikes) and can see whether or not people have spores on them, but not how many. During this time he will not be able to see or write in the public chat (like having to talkie), even with brainsynch. No one can invite him into a private chat, even when in the same room. When the 3 cycles end, he can behave as usual.

Okay, this skill miiiight need some reworking but I wasn't able to come up with a decent skill that fits his character at level 6 for now. Maybe someone else gets a better idea - generally I would be aiming for a skill that can benefit with and without Mush onboard.

Phew, that was time consuming. I hope you like those!

Greetz,
res7less
On april 24, 2016
Darksteel

Heh, alright if we can do character suggestions here, I made two based on characters who could have easily boarded the Daedalus.

Kivanç Terzi
Replacing Paola Rinaldo.

A standard cut and swap might be all that's needed for an interesting development; Kivanç sits at the number 2 spot for Comms Manager, second only to Paola. [Therein, he will always be Comms Manager on seasons that feature him.] Additionally he would be very easy to add in a timeline switch, just have his rescue op occur and for whatever reason have Paola stay behind. 6th in line for NERON Administrator and 15th in line for Commander.

Level 1 Skill: Rebel
A high end skill for Paola becomes standard for Kivanç, this is balanced by skills that Paola would have either being higher tiered or unavailable all together.

Level 2 Skill: Radio Expert
Simple enough logic, he was part of the duo who ran a pirate radio station after all.

Level 3 Skill: Polymath
Centered around his job, this useful skill would give him a free IT point a day as well as those always handy extra chat channels, not as powerful as IT Expert, but still very helpful.

Level 4 Skill: Technician
Akin to Paola having Bioglogist, Kivanç has Technician to give him a function beyond intercepting garbled space transmissions. Backed up in his backstory by him having set up radio transmitters.

Level 5 Skill: Determined
This skill has excellent sync with Technician, but it's presence at skill slot 5 acts more as a wall to his final skill.

Level 6 Skill: Communicator
His final, and only unique skill; This powerful Mush hunting tool allows the user to see the last private message that the target sent. Though it does not say who it was sent too. Messages sent on the Mush Channel do not count as Private Messages, and are not checked.. It Costs 3 AP or 1 to use.
The message that the target sent is posted in a private log that only Kivanç can read.
On april 24, 2016
Darksteel

Nils Carlsson
Replacing Stephen Seagull.
This is an easy one to imagine, Nils just get's his spot in the meat locker over everyone's favorite stowaway. In essence, we replace a generalist with a researcher, not the craziest thing in the world but it may make the research progression faster than average, so he comes with a handicapping trait...

Trait: Chronically Ill
Nils suffers from a debilitating disease of some form, [I could not find reference to what it is he suffers from though. :/] As such, all actions cost an additional AP. [Bonus; as it is based on an illness, it is not active when Mush; he still has an outward appearance of having the trait, but is not effected by it.]

Skill 1: Biologist
The stock standard skill for any researcher; his years of researching Chun for the purpose of curing the Mush infection helps him greatly.

Skill 2: Mycologist
A pretty simple skill; his reason for having it is simple; He has spent a good portion of his life researching Mushrooms.

Skill 3: The Optimist
A skill used as filler, useful to a member of the research crew who is rarely in the dorms soaking up Shrink bonuses.

Skill 4: Competent
Nils' first unique skill; it's use is simple; it reduces the AP cost of researching by one, neutralizing his hindering trait when he is researching; it has the additional effect of giving a passive +10% Success rate to all actions.

Skill 5: Genius
This skill is a useful [Though not extremely] addition to Nils' arsenal, intended for spontaneously completing harder research like the Retro-Funal Serum.

Skill 6: Researcher
Nils' second unique skill; He is counted as a Medic, but does not have the Surgery with Medikit option or the extra healing bonus; instead, it gives guaranteed top percentage research for him alone. [Like NERON's only friend, but it only effects Nils.]
On april 27, 2016
[9338706]

XP Gaining

I think the current xp system should be revamped to reward active and hardworking crews. Currently, everyone gains 1/2 xp per cycle regardless of rather they are just being completely inactive or putting in alot of effort. I feel that if XP rewarded skilled play, it could motivate players into more positive behavior.

First, I think xp should increase for humans once a ship hits Day 5 and Day 10. So the starting xp gained would be 1/2, and on day 5 would become 2/3, and day 10 the cycle xp would max out 3/4. This would of course make players want to keep their ship standing as long as possible and will create a positive gameplay environment instead of just "I don't like this character/ship, going inactive". This bonus would only apply to humans and Mush would just receive 2/3xp all cycles since their goal is to destroy the ship.

Second, I think the xp should be rewarded on success/failure of the game. If human players return to Sol without any Mush they should be rewarded +25xp and if they also have the serum developed they should get +50xp. Human also should be rewarded +100xp if they return to Eden and +150xp if they have the serum. For Mush, the opposite would be true. If they destroy the Daedalus or infiltrate Sol they should receive +50xp. And if they Infiltrate Eden they should receive +150xp. With -25xp being subtracted from each infiltration total if the humans have the serum.

Third, I think Mush should receive XP for every infection. Each human infected should give +10xp. This will motivate positive Mush behavior and will make infecting the entire crew the best possible option for Mush instead of more "dirty" tactics.

Of course these numbers will need to be adjusted so that players won't speed threw leveling characters but overall I think these changes would be positive for the Mush experience.
On april 27, 2016
[8886413]
AvarieXP Gaining

I think the current xp system should be revamped to reward active and hardworking crews. Currently, everyone gains 1/2 xp per cycle regardless of rather they are just being completely inactive or putting in alot of effort. I feel that if XP rewarded skilled play, it could motivate players into more positive behavior.

First, I think xp should increase for humans once a ship hits Day 5 and Day 10. So the starting xp gained would be 1/2, and on day 5 would become 2/3, and day 10 the cycle xp would max out 3/4. This would of course make players want to keep their ship standing as long as possible and will create a positive gameplay environment instead of just "I don't like this character/ship, going inactive". This bonus would only apply to humans and Mush would just receive 2/3xp all cycles since their goal is to destroy the ship.

Second, I think the xp should be rewarded on success/failure of the game. If human players return to Sol without any Mush they should be rewarded +25xp and if they also have the serum developed they should get +50xp. Human also should be rewarded +100xp if they return to Eden and +150xp if they have the serum. For Mush, the opposite would be true. If they destroy the Daedalus or infiltrate Sol they should receive +50xp. And if they Infiltrate Eden they should receive +150xp. With -25xp being subtracted from each infiltration total if the humans have the serum.

Third, I think Mush should receive XP for every infection. Each human infected should give +10xp. This will motivate positive Mush behavior and will make infecting the entire crew the best possible option for Mush instead of more "dirty" tactics.

Of course these numbers will need to be adjusted so that players won't speed threw leveling characters but overall I think these changes would be positive for the Mush experience.

Hmm... It's interesting, but has a few issues: Will only living crew be able to gain their exp? What about crew who give up their lives to further the life of the crew (e.g, going on a O2 planet with a volcano to try and save the ship, and dying). What about inactives? How will this system be automated, since this would be a lot to be done manually?

Also, the condition: Destroying the ship by mush, what if the ship is so inactive that it dies by itself? Do they still gain exp? What if they are dead?

What about casting ships, where the no mush option has the potential to generate lots of exp through pilgred rushes by spamming ships? Would it be fair to disable exp gain for casting ships, since people with gold days will lose out?
It's a lot to discuss in one post, so I'm not going to try. Maybe if there was a thread dedicated to discussing the issue of exp gain, it's almost as big as the glory system honestly.
On april 27, 2016
[9338706]

@zazyman32 Wow alot of question xD. Yes only living crew members will receive xp bonus. I like this game alot because of the psychological aspects. The way I look at it, a sacrifice is a sacrifice. Life is worthwhile and giving up possible xp you could gain in the future to further the life of your crew is pretty noble as it should. At the moment it's just like "Oh well might as well die, doesn't matter that much". On the other hand, those who died will still receive "Winning XP" making a sacrifice for the greater good possibly self-advantageous.

Personally I think inactives should receive no xp. When they have the inactive status, they should receive no xp and even if they come back they will lose any oppurtunity for bonus XP at Day 5/10.

If the Ship is destroyed without Mush interfering, they should still receive the bonus XP. Afterall there are only 2 Mush so I can't see this being abused.

As far as casting ships, not sure about that one. Would definitely like some input on how to avoid abuse.

thing is, people can actually have trouble for getting online for like a day or so due to real life, say they had to go out somewhere, or they were busier than expected. It's very hard to discriminate and draw a line whilst being fair.

I don't see moderators checking for fair play on a casting ship. Over in RP or Die! we run themes, and the xp thing could be rather dodgy and off-balancing.

On may 14, 2016
Joefesok

Oh hey, it looks like it's time to suggest silver mode be made free. Possibly again, I can't tell.

So here, have a bunch of reasons I think it would work which are not (exclusively) just "because I don't want to spend money on the game."

How it should be done.
Pretty simply, actually. Silver mode should still be able to be earned by purchasing gold mode, however, it can now be earned via commendations, in increments, ala casting settings.

For example, getting 500 (?) would unlock the iTrackie.

So what actual benefit is there to this?
There's lots.
In no particular order,
Good players who wouldn't keep playing the game may stay.
I know a couple of people who are pretty good at the game and are pretty fun people to be around. They played mush, had a blast, then left because the game was permanently stacked against them unless they paid.
I'm not going to justify that mindset because I personally dislike that mindset. However, these were good players. Had they stayed, the community in general would benefit from having better players around.
Ships survive longer.
Because more players with Silver are in circulation, even if it's simply marginally more, ships now have easier times getting to eden, or surviving for longer periods. The benefits of this are twofold:
-More gold days will be bought for pub ships which players think will last longer.
-New players will have fewer bad ships due to the slack being carried by Silver, experienced players.
The inequity is less daunting to new players.
Players which formerly would not play nor support Mush due to thinking its business model was unfair may be encouraged to play the game again. There still exists inequity between Silver and Gold, however, it is not as large as Bronze and Silver or Bronze and Gold.
There is a new long-term goal.
Experienced Bronze players may have reached the end of their progression and can have a new goal. A weak argument, I know, but one all the same.
Bad players are encouraged to be friendly.
The daunting reward of Silver may be enough of an incentive to have bad players co-operate with their teams instead of continuing to be toxic.

This is just my take on making Silver free. Thoughts?
On may 14, 2016
Veren

you just have to join an arkadeo clan and / or kadokado
each can provide you a MTpass in a few months (take more times on kadokado i think )

probably way faster than your plan (i'm close to get 10 MTpass just from arkadeo but have "only" 452
meaning i could easily buy 5 silver mode from arkadeo but couldn't get any from your suggestion even if i play from the very begining

On may 17, 2016
[9338706]

Pretty simple suggestion on "room damage". I suggest that room damage only be applied when hunters attack or an asteroid hits. It just feels weird that the ship status is calm yet panels and room shakes are happening. If room damage occurs while hunters are attacking the ship, it would be more realistic. Room damage could also occur all over the ship if it is hit by an asteroid.

Also think the same should happen with fires instead of it being completely random. Fires could have a small chance of occurring when a hunter hits The Daedalus, when a crew member cooks something, or when a ship takes of, ect. Ultimately I think these "random cycle events" should be connected to occurrences that could actually cause them.

Lauxnos

A tiny asteroid that went unnoticed by the ship's sensors hit our ship's hull and loosened some steel plates that subsequently fell down on Terrence.
Stuff can happen in space and what you're suggesting would change the game too much. It would put too much focus on the hunters and the occurrences would become much more predictable.

On june 8, 2016
Sachiko

On die2note, until you have gathered 100 soul points by playing in varous towns, you're only limited to Small Towns. Once you have 100 soul points, you can finally join "distant region" towns which have bigger maps and a slightly increased difficulty level. The Soul Point tier thing can be bypassed tho as any person with 100+ points can form a coalition with someone who doesn't have 100 and then jump, thus dragging said person into a distant town.
On june 8, 2016
Enigma

It's a gating system, so before the character selection screen you'd get another screen that said for example "Young Crew" and "Veteran Crew" and you wouldn't be able to join a "Veteran Crew" until you had a certain amount of XP.

The impact on the newbie ships would be that they would ONLY be populated by other newbies with less than the set XP level, although if it was a copy of D2N then you could actively choose to join these newbie ships.

From my experience (14 ships) I don't think it's needed here because it would just create an long and awkward barrier to new players before they can reach the "Veteran Crews", and people could leave before ever really getting to see what the game was supposed to be.
On june 8, 2016
blackgem

To me, the already existing problem is that newbies come in, and are either intimidated, confused or simply don't like the game. We don't need ships that are 'cancer' that make it worse, so that the community stagnates. That's part of the reason we don't like it when someone pretends to be a newbie.

That's a suggestion that has always been refused by the devs. Beginners need to learn the game, and learn to appreciate it. They will be able to if they can play with people who teach them and who show them was a good active ship is. On june 8, 2016
blackgem

Hm. That gives me an idea.
The Griefer Button. Similar to report, perhaps under the same tab. Indicate this person is a griefer. These are seen to almost immediately depending on mod onlineness. It gives a possibiltiy for the griefing player to simply be removed from the ship, depending if it's found they're actually griefing. In this way, the crew is relieved of having to use their AP to take out a griefer.
Now I will shoot my own idea down: Mods cannot be online 24/7. This could add quite a burden to our mods, which would be unfair. Additionally, griefers themselves could spam the Grief Button in order to cause our mods more trouble then they should have. Beyond that, post-Mush selection, there's always the possibility of a Mush rampager being reported as a griefer, and then if the person does not get removed from the ship, it shows that they were not griefing, but are probably a Mush. This seems like a very meta and almost unavoidable Mush test.
My apology for the paragraph.
On june 8, 2016
[1820396]

Reading Peanutz' post, I'm wondering: Does anybod know what the reasoning behind Die2Nite system is?

I mean, I played it long time ago during sesons 1 and 2, when, as far as I remember, no such thing existed. And I'm curious why would devs implement such a thing, as the game doesn't seem much more straightforward then Mush. Seems like the way to drive newbies away instead of introducing and teaching them how to play the game.
Does anyone here has any insight into this?
On june 8, 2016
Sachiko
Patches1984

Reading Peanutz' post, I'm wondering: Does anybod know what the reasoning behind Die2Nite system is?

I mean, I played it long time ago during sesons 1 and 2, when, as far as I remember, no such thing existed. And I'm curious why would devs implement such a thing, as the game doesn't seem much more straightforward then Mush. Seems like the way to drive newbies away instead of introducing and teaching them how to play the game.
Does anyone here has any insight into this?

Because small towns are a lot like tutorial towns. They are easier to play in. they start with some buildings pre-built and the maps are small. Small towns are there for newbies to get familiar with the game mechanics & whatnot. Players with over 100 SP who join small towns actually get a spiritual guide distinction if the town lives past Day 8 I think it was.
On june 8, 2016
sperbi

Before I started playing mush, I was playing the german version of Die2nite for a long time.

As new player you started in the small maps, noone was able to go very far away from town,. since map was so small and of course the way to do things was not always the same as in distant random towns.
It took me around 9 towns to leave the small maps, while I had 5 towns which gave me only 0-3 soul points. The soul points increase exponentially with days survived, so there may be people who need 50 towns, but it is also possible to need only 4 towns or less.

But after the small towns I knew already that much of the game, that I was a good help in my third distant town, which got a ranking #4.

I think the reason of the small map - concept was to sieve the people and I guess, if there are many people trying out the game, then mostly only the learn - willing and interested players, who don't need much motivation from other people to play longer will leave the small maps and are ready for the distant regions, while the other people may stay stucked in the small towns until they loose interest of the game.
And this is not a problem actually, if you have many people joining the small towns in the first place.

If there are not many people trying out the game, then probably the chance is less likely to keep many of them, since you may also have more people who are spreading nonsense or behave differently than majority in distant regions.

Aceb

On august 1, 2016
N_Faker

Chun skill change for Lethargy.
Increase the AP gain from +1 to +2 after 4 consecutive cycles in a bed.
It will enable Chun to fill her AP bar to max from 0 to 24 in 8 cycles
instead of from 0 to 20 (0 to 23 in 9 cycles).

Overall AP gain from the skill would increase from +4(~4,4 at optimal efficiency) to +8

The skill would be become slightly more convenient and powerful, while retaining the incredible inconvenience of being bound to a bed, in addition to requiring partners to spend the accumulated AP efficiently.

idea
the distiller will no longer produce one pill a day instead u can make pills by extracting properties out of fruits.

lets say we have 3 fruits that give +1 ap +1 morale +1 hp +1 satisfaction and cures vertigo.
we could make 5 pills from it a +3 ap pill a +3 morale pill and 3 cure's vertigo pill's
so we get 5 pills and the fruit's will disappear.
(if u get too much vertigo pills u can select to only make the morale/ap pill's)

the ap/mp/morale cap for pills stay like they are now but pills will be able to cure more disease's. health and satisfaction from the fruit will be lost

biologist's gets free points each day to make pill's whit the distiller.

[8886413]

That's actually pretty cool. What about having to freeze the fruit and having to use it as a "focus". Pills are made based around the plant, but if you want to change the pill (or perhaps after it decays, but freezing it gets past that) then the plant gets destroyed.

[8744424]

Yet the game is more fun and unpredictable with injuries info being private, imo.
